—I direct a question to the Minister for Trade Negotiations. Will the Minister inform the House whether Australia supports the proposal of the United States last week to reform world agricultural trade? Will he indicate to the House the progress that was made on other trade issues during his recent visit to the United States?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to say that the United States trade talks held in Washington from 18 to 20 October were conducted in a most positive atmosphere. Unlike previous similar talks, both sides had no major irritants to deal with. However, I did reiterate Australia's general concerns on issues such as US subsidies and particularly the export enhancement program, possible changes to that country's sugar policy, and the drafting of the 1990 United States Farm Bill. I raised these issues in talks with the United States Special Trade Representative, Carla Hills, and at meetings with other members of the Administration and Congress.

ANSWER.PARA: From Australia's point of view, two major positive developments came out of the talks. The first was a briefing by the Administration on the proposal, which the USA has subsequently tabled in Geneva, for reforming world agricultural trade. At that stage it had not been tabled but we were briefed fully on it. What the USA has tabled is a realistic and detailed proposal which, if implemented, would restore fairness to agricultural trade.

In essence, what the United States is proposing is that all countries move to a system where, firstly, access to agricultural markets would only be restricted by tariffs which would reduce over time, getting rid of that multiplicity of non-tariff measures; secondly, export subsidies would be prohibited after five years; and, thirdly, a system for domestic support for farmers would be introduced whereby the most trade distorting policies would be prohibited, and supports not linked to production would be the only ones that would be tolerated.

Clearly such a set of rules would be in Australia's interests and of great benefit to Australian farmers. We support the approach which has been tabled by the United States and on which we were briefed in Washington the week before last. It is now for other countries, including Japan and the European Community, to consider this United States proposal, which is a radical proposal but a very sound one. If they want to see progress in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) talks as a whole, it is essential that those other countries direct their minds to this proposal.

The other issue I want to touch on briefly is that I am pleased to report that under the agreement reached with the United States Australia will be permitted to increase very substantially its steel exports to the United States-a market in which steel imports have been tightly controlled under the voluntary restraint arrangements. Both of these developments are of particular significance to Australia. The steel decision creates trade opportunities immediately while the agricultural proposal has the potential to flow through to unprecedented agricultural exports if other countries can be encouraged to agree to the very sensible approach that the United States Administration is putting forward.

One final point that I make on behalf of the Government is to refer to the efforts of government officials both in Canberra and overseas in their excellent work both in the long drawn-out GATT negotiations-a process which is of course ongoing-and in ensuring that a very constructive environment existed for the Australia-United States commercial relations.

—Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the House of the effectiveness of the Government's quarantine policies in protecting Australian agriculture?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Rankin for his question. There is a bit of a campaign on at present. Some quarantine issues are being beaten up by the Opposition. The focus for this at present is the fact that we took the decision that we could no longer ban imports of Canadian pig meat because of disease. Australia is about the only country now that has been banning pig meat from Canada on quarantine grounds. After five years of consultation and trials, we decided to allow it in. It has been allowed freely into New Zealand for quite some time.

ANSWER.PARA: To get back to the more general thrust of the question, in 1987 I established the Lindsay Committee to review quarantine policies to ensure that we have the best assessment of quarantine risks and the best systems to counter these risks. This review followed decades of nonsensical attempts to impose a no risk assessment, regardless of the fact that there is no such thing as no risk. To achieve this, one would simply have to ban people, airplanes, ships and everything else from coming into Australia.

The practical effect was that quarantine was being used, in some instances, as a trade barrier and that is something that the Australian agricultural sector strongly opposes. We know that in the real world other countries, such as the European Economic Community, do impose quarantine barriers as a trade measure. The Government's policy is that quarantine is neither a trade barrier nor a trade lever. Quarantine decisions are taken on quarantine grounds alone. Some of the people whipping this issue up seem to want to use quarantine as a trade barrier most of the time or use it as trade leverage when it suits.

The Lindsay Committee supported the quarantine grounds only policy and recommended a formal transparent procedure based on assessed risk with significant industry input for taking quarantine decisions and allocating quarantine resources. The Government accepted those recommendations. The procedure is that there is an assessment not only of the biology of the threat but also of the strategies for countering the risks and the costs and benefits involved. The industry is fully consulted. That is pretty sensible; it is strategic management.

We take into account the pest, where it comes from, how it spreads and the biological consequences. We also take into account the strategies for exclusion and the risks of entry under those strategies. We also put into place in our assessment the costs and benefits of continued exclusion. In that way we can come to profiles on the various pests that we want to keep out of this country. For example, the profile of foot and mouth disease is such that there is simply no way that this disease can be allowed to come into this country. At the other end of the spectrum there are lesser diseases and pests. Beyond that, we are also implementing more comprehensive disease preparedness arrangements so that outbreaks can be dealt with. Again, a strategic approach is being adopted. The response must be tailored to the risks.

This approach does not mean the abandonment of a strong quarantine policy. We are not opening the floodgates to disease. On the contrary, we are shutting them as firmly as is possible under any system run by human beings. This logic does not worry the Opposition, which has been running round scaring people and implying support for the nonsensical notion that there is such a thing as zero risk. The Opposition's hypocrisy on this issue is exposed in its so-called economic policy, the electoral bribe which promises a cut of $23m, or 14 per cent, to the budget of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. What would that do to Australia's quarantine preparedness? It would mean bigger risks. It would mean being forced to respond after the event at greater cost. It would mean a `fingers crossed' approach to quarantine and disease preparedness. So not only has the Opposition repudiated its earlier promises to increase quarantine resources but also it is now planning to place Australia's entire agricultural sector at risk.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the mid-1970s--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—I warn the honourable member for Flinders.

—The authorities-as the questioner puts it-have been aware of the problem of the absence of capital taxation since the mid-1970s. One of the central reasons why the Government introduced a capital gains tax was to curtail the opportunities for tax avoidance and evasion. Honourable members will recall the massive fraud perpetrated on the Commonwealth via the bottom of the harbour tax avoidance schemes during the period of the previous Government. I remind honourable members of what special prosecutor Roger Gyles said in his 1984 report. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Tax avoidance and evasion of this kind in such volume is extraordinary in absolute terms but almost incredible in relative terms having regard to the small Australian economy.

What members should be aware of is that the whole basis of the bottom of the harbour tax schemes was the conversion of taxable company income into untaxable capital gains. What basically happened was that the act of selling the company to the promoter was the act that converted current year profits into a tax free capital gain. The bottom of the harbour aspect arose when those companies were then onsold to directors who had no assets. What was underpinning the whole scheme was the absence of capital gains taxation. In 1982 when the former Treasurer was flushed out by the McCabe-Lafranchi report the honourable member for Bennelong had this to say:
These are cases in which shareholders of companies--

TALK.START.PARA: —Dawkins should explain--
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw.
—Mr Howard said:

ANSWER.PARA: These are cases in which shareholders of companies were selling their shares in circumstances where there were associated arrangements under which the target companies were stripped of funds and left in a position where the companies could not pay the income tax that would in the normal course of events be assessed to them. The shareholders received the profits of the companies in a tax-free capital form, not diminished in any way by either company tax or tax on dividends but only by the fee charged by the promoter for his services.

That put in a nutshell the whole basis of the boom in tax avoidance. The Australian Taxation Office had been consistently advising the then Government from 1977 about the absence of tax avoidance. I remind the House of former Commissioner O'Reilly's historic letter of 1977 in which, when dealing with sales of companies with current profits, he said:
These sales also give rise to problems of avoidance by way of dividend stripping.
The absence of a capital gains tax increases the difficulty of devising provisions that would result in tax being payable on these profits without exposing true capital gains to tax.
In 1978, Commissioner O'Reilly said:

The basic avoidance technique is to arrange that a large share of income is diverted from a family business trust to an entity that, by one means or another, escaping paying tax on the income. The family receives the income, diminished by the promoter's fee, in a non-taxable capital form.
In 1980 he wrote to the Government:

For so long as we do not have a tax on capital gains, and do not tax gifts, I do not see that a solution lies in attempting to collect the tax from those people in whose favour companies and trusts are stripped.

The fact is that, right through the period 1975-80, with a myriad of letters beginning in 1977, the then Taxation Commissioner was enjoining the Government to introduce capital gains taxation because underlying all these schemes was the absence of capital gains taxation. But, instead of that, the former Government chose to stumble down the road and to try to prevent bottom of the harbour schemes by trying to determine the motives of vendors, not to deal with the problem at source. It was simply putting plugs in the cracks in the dam wall rather than building a new wall, rather than dealing with the problem as it really was at its source.

Then we had the famous statement from the honourable member for Bennelong, the former Treasurer, in 1982 that public opinion at the time was not strongly against the avoidance schemes. Of course it was not strongly against avoidance schemes because the people did not know about them. But, like so many things, the gaping hole was left for this Government to repair. The basic structural defect was left for us to repair by putting in a capital gains tax. But what have we now? The same crowd is trying to remove the very tax that stopped the tax avoidance. The very essence of the change which prevents this kind of scam today is now to be removed. Yesterday Mr McCrann, the noted business columnist, was talking about the indecency and inequity of removing the capital gains tax and saying that we will see the resources of the country turn to paper profits and tax avoidance schemes once more. Those opposite are at it again. Not content with destroying the tax system and making a swill of it in the 1970s and early 1980s, they are now about to try to give tens of billions of dollars of unrealised capital gains liability back to one per cent of the taxpaying population. That is not public policy; it is public theft.

Those opposite are using their powers as a parliamentary party to try to change the tax laws to benefit one per cent of the population by a shift of wealth that this country has never seen the likes of and no other country has even seen the likes of. Billions of dollars would be transferred from contingent tax liabilities in the hands of the Commonwealth to private individuals, many of whom are in the Opposition parties or influential in those parties, including on their front bench. Those opposite reserve for themselves the right to think that they can change the tax laws of this country to confer these billions of dollars of benefits on people as though it were a legitimate public policy change when it is nothing short of public theft.

Anyone in British politics who sent the British economy into a recession and the rest would never appear again. But oh no, those three are back again, large as life, cocky as you like, saying `We can do it all again'.

What does the Opposition propose in its policy? Basically it proposes a set of bribes and then a set of give-aways, the most outrageous of which is the capital gains tax. It cannot even keep together the basic fabric of the structure that the Government has put in place. We have done the hard work and put the capital gains tax in place. We have taken the political risks and put it there. The Opposition does not have the decency or the common sense to understand that something of value has been done and that it should be preserved. Oh no, the Opposition thinks it can give one per cent of the tax paying public tens of billions of accumulated contingent tax liabilities sitting there. It thinks it can hand them over. As I said, it is not the legitimate operation of a party thinking about a better policy structure with a proposal for a change in public policy. It is a proposal for public theft; that is what it is. It is on that basis that I move the following amendment, to put some real substance in the debate:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

(1) this House notes the widespread criticism of the proposal of the Leader of the Opposition to abolish the capital gains tax, and in particular, the disastrous consequences for the economic health of the nation of the proposal;
(2) consequently, this House believes the Leader of the Opposition must provide the public with a detailed account of:
(a) what prompted the Opposition to backdate its proposed concessionary speculative gains tax to 19 September 1985;

(b) on what basis has the Opposition calculated that the revenue cost of their proposal would be $450m a year, and to what extent does this costing include an allowance for the realisation of windfall tax-free capital gains derived from the backdating of the Coalition's proposal;

(c) to what extent does the Opposition's costing make allowance for increased tax avoidance, the potential for which was described by Business Commentator Mr Terry McCrann in the Melbourne Sunday Herald on October 29, 1989 as follows:

Mr Peacock proposes to turn back the clock and once again unleash the assembled might of the legal, accounting and financial professions in the drive to turn otherwise taxable income into tax-free capital gains of five years' standing. That is unacceptable-not only on equity grounds, but in terms of promoting the very changes necessary to make Australia more competitive and more efficient. We don't want our best brains and available resources devoted to shuffling bits of paper for tax and financial reasons. Better they be directed to investing in and building real businesses;
(d) to what extent does the President of the Liberal Party and Chairman of Elders IXL, Mr John Elliott, benefit from the Opposition's proposed changes to the Capital Gains Tax;
(e) to what extent does the Liberal Party Candidate for Barker and Director of Elders IXL, Mr Ian McLachlan, benefit from the Opposition's proposed changes to the Capital Gains Tax;

(f) the discussions that took place between Mr Elliott and the Leader of the Opposition prior to the latter's challenge for the Leadership of the Liberal Party and what discussion was there of the Opposition's proposed changes to the Capital Gains Tax;

(g) similarly, what discussions, correspondence or other communications have taken place between the Shadow Treasurer or his office and Mr Elliott or his advisers on the structure of the Opposition's capital gains tax proposal;

(h) what prompted the Leader of the Opposition to tell the Metal Trades Industry Association on 23 October that ``countless millions'' of taxpayers pay capital gains tax, when statistics of the Australian Taxation Office show that less than one per cent of individual taxpayers paid capital gains tax in respect of the 1987-88 income year;

(i) what has prompted the Leader of the Opposition to claim that his is a proposal to help small business when more than two-thirds of the capital gains tax payable by companies is paid by the largest 1 1/2 per cent of Australian companies;

(j) whether it is Opposition policy, as stated by the Leader of the National Party in his address to the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association last week, that exploration `farm-out' agreements will be exempt from the Opposition's so-called Speculative Gains Tax? and why was this exemption not included in the Opposition's so-called Economic Action Plan; and
(k) what other exemptions from its Speculative Gains Tax proposal has the Opposition agreed to but not detailed in its Economic Action Plan and what is the revenue cost of these exemptions?

The amendment calls on the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) to provide the public with a detailed answer to these questions. In particular, the amendment asks the Leader of the Opposition to provide an account about what discussions, correspondence or other communications have taken place between the shadow Treasurer or his office and Mr Elliott or his advisers on the structure of the Opposition's capital gains tax proposal, particularly around the Harlin Holdings proposal. Tell us about the relationships and the questions about--
Dr Hewson interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are not. I know that Elliott was in touch with the shadow Treasurer's office about Harlin; I know he was in touch with his office about the structure of the shadow Treasurer's proposal, because Harlin does not succeed unless one goes back to September 1985. I repeat: Harlin does not succeed in terms of capital gains treatment unless one goes back to September 1985. Let the Leader of the Opposition tell us whether, in his discussions with Mr Elliott prior to the change in leadership, the capital gains tax issue and the backdating to September 1985 was discussed. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to tell us these things and then we will see what veracity there is in the Opposition Leader's claim that this is just a change in public policy. It is a fact that the proposal is for the largest transfer of wealth of the public's contingent capital gains tax liability as taxpayers to the Commonwealth in the nation's history.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get a real issue on the table of the House of Representatives and not some phony proposition from the shadow Treasurer about fiscal responsibility when members opposite in fact bequeathed to us the most disastrous fiscal inheritance in the nation's history. I would not be bothered tabling once again the note from the then Secretary to the Treasury saying that the speed of the fiscal deterioration in Australia was unparalleled in the post-war years. If my memory serves me correctly, he might have said, unparalleled in our peacetime history. That is what the Secretary to the Treasury said in the note that was given to the then Treasurer before the 1983 election-the fastest deterioration in fiscal policy ever. Who was left to clean it up? The shadow Treasurer has the temerity to come in today and say that, because my colleague the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) refers to the wage-tax trade-off of this year-which is, of course, the successful plugging of a wage explosion-and speculates about the prospect of such an economic technique being employed again, the Government would then have some kind of irresponsible fiscal policy. That is why we will have wages growth of 6.5 to 6.75 per cent this year instead of about 15 per cent which we would have had under the Opposition parties, which would then have been followed by a crash landing, a recession.

The Government's plan did work and, despite the cynicism that it was greeted with as being an election ploy and the rest, it was a necessary part of economic policy. The Government will make judgments in the future about what is required in terms of wages and fiscal policy. As I said the other day, the requirements of fiscal policy will be paramount: that is, the question of demand will be paramount. The Government's stance on fiscal policy for the coming year will be determined in the coming year and all other judgments will be contingent upon that requirement, a requirement of a reduction in demand. So the Opposition's proposition is fraudulent and without any basis.

I want the shadow Treasurer to face up to his claim about his different world and to tell us what kind of world he believes exists, what kind of different world exonerates him from the laws of economics. What kind of different world frees him of the laws of economics and the behaviour of economic aggregates and economic variables? Let the shadow Treasurer tell us that, because if any one of the rest of us said something like that he would be beaten to a pulp by the media of this country, as he deserves to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition asks one fundamental question of this Government: Where is the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe)? Why did he skulk out of this chamber like a dog with its tail between its legs? Why is he not here to face up to an issue which he and he alone put on the public agenda of this nation by way of the contents of his release in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning? We have been told by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), as we were by the Minister at Question Time, that it is all just a terrible mistake, that what he said was not said. For the benefit of the House I will put on the record exactly what the article states:

SPEECH.PARA: `In April this year you got the largest tax cuts in history a massive $5.8 billion.'
Mr Howe went on to say:
`And probably in a tax-wage trade-off next year-
honourable members should note it is next year, not this year, as both he and the Treasurer claimed-
you'll get something of the same order. All paid for,' Mr Howe said.

The issue is quite straightforward; the Minister has been caught out very seriously. One could even ask whether he was actually prepared to influence the contents of this article which appeared in the newspaper. Was he capable of doing that? If he was here, perhaps he could tell us, but he is not.

We want to know, the Australian people want to know, and the millions of Australian social security beneficiaries want to know what the hidden agenda is that this Government has up its sleeve. Perhaps the Government's response to our Economic Action Plan was so pathetic because we got in first. Maybe the Government also has an action plan based on cutting back government expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it?

—My colleague asks what it is. What is the great mystery? Why will the Government not tell the Australian people? Why will it not tell this Parliament? Why is the Minister not here? I come back to that fundamental question: Who better to tell the truth, something we find almost impossible to extricate from Ministers of this Government, than the person who gave the interview in the first place?

SPEECH.PARA: The facts of the situation simply are that we know why the Treasurer and the Minister for Social Security made such a pathetic response to our Economic Action Plan. It is because they know and we know that our policy is right, but we got there first. The Australian people accepted our message. They know it is right. In a matter of a few months the Government will see in the hard realities of the ballot box what the outcome will be for its failure to face up to the real economic difficulties facing this country, as we have, and to do something about it.

What the Minister for Social Security has inadvertently announced has revealed the Hawke Labor Government's desperation to be re-elected at any price-in this case nearly $6 billion. That is the price that the Government is prepared to pay to once again bribe its way into office. After seven Budgets and seven failures, and economic indices being wrong on almost every occasion, the Government's credibility in the marketplace of Australia's voter-land is near zero. That is what the Government has to face up to. That is what the Australian people will remember in a few months' time, and that is why we need to know now and the Australian people need to know now precisely what the Government's big tax cuts in the pipeline will be and, above all, how the Government will pay for them.

The Minister for Social Security has not said how they will be funded. He has said that they will all be paid for. But how do the members of this Parliament and how do the people of Australia understand what those tax cuts mean unless they also know what is on the other side of that particular piece of coinage? Where are the cuts to be made? If they are to be unfunded, the Treasurer's entire economic strategy will be destroyed. I venture to guess that the reason the Minister for Social Security is not in the chamber is that those commitments are unfunded. Why did he have the Treasurer here to defend him? Because the Treasurer had no alternative but to face up to the reality that his economic policy now has a gaping hole in it; a hole put in it by none other than his colleague of the Left, the Minister for Social Security.

The facts are that if these cuts are not fully funded, injecting a further $6 billion of unfunded tax cuts and benefits will have catastrophic effects on inflation, on the balance of payments and, above all, on international confidence in Australia's currency. The sad part is that such a policy will destroy utterly and forever the very people, the disadvantaged, whom the Minister for Social Security claims so often to represent.

The Minister not only has told us about the Government's re-election strategy but also has confirmed that it has its own hidden agenda for reducing expenditure. Once again I quote his words. He said they would be `all paid for'. What we want to know and what any sensible Australian voter wants to know is what is on the other side of the coin. If they are to be paid for, how? If they are to be paid for, who are the losers? If they are to be paid for, who are the winners? What do we get from the Government? We get silence; absolute, abject silence, backed up by this putrid performance by the Treasurer, throwing aspersions on my colleague the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), hiding behind aspersions as a miserable alternative to sensible, soundly based debate, because the facts, which are so abundantly clear, are that the Government has no case, it has nothing to present to the Australian people, and it has been caught out once again.

Unlike Labor, the Opposition has no hidden agenda. Our family package is fully funded from the responsible expenditure cuts contained in our Economic Action Plan. We have announced it and, unlike Labor's scheme, it is there for all to see. In addition, we are committed to returning bracket creep each year and not giving phoney tax cuts paid out of the massive tax receipts obtained from higher inflation which has made Australians today the generation of highest taxpayers this century. There has been no such commitment from Labor. It has made a virtue of higher taxes. It is those higher taxes and those higher taxes alone which are the fundamental basis, the fulcrum, of what the Minister for Social Security inadvertently perhaps let out in that interview. The Minister must tell us where Labor will cut expenditure and where the Minister for Social Security especially will cut expenditure in his area of responsibility.

In July, on television, he said categorically that there was no rorting of the welfare system. I was there. I heard it with absolute amazement. To say I was silenced would be an incorrect statement, but certainly he ought to have been. On 25 July, he was interviewed on A Current Affair with Jana Wendt as follows:
Jana Wendt. ``. . . Mr Howe, is the dole system being rorted?''
That was a straightforward question. The interview continued:
Brian Howe: ``Well, no, the figures I think are very clear . . .''
Jana Wendt: ``Is the system being rorted or not?''
Brian Howe: ``Well no.''
Jana Wendt: ``Categorically not?''
Brian Howe: ``No.''

Remember that. He said, `No'. The welfare system is wide open to massive abuse. If that were not the case, why does the Budget contain a whole range of changes to tighten up the system? If that were not the case, why did he say only in the last few days-in fact, last Sunday-on the Face to Face program:
I think there is always scope to be rigorous.

Was that a warning? Was it a warning to the dole bludgers, the cheats and the welfare fraud artists? Or was it a warning to the hundreds of thousands if not millions of Australian families and people who are on welfare benefits, and legitimately on those benefits? What is the meaning of the word `rigorous' which he used last Sunday? Where does it fit in with this little story in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning? Surely as an Opposition we are doing our duty to the Australian people in asking the Government, in asking the Minister at the table, the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), `Where is your hidden agenda? How are you going to fund further tax cuts and some welfare benefit increases to the tune of some $6 billion a year?'.

The Minister has given us a warning of what is in the pipeline. What we ask is to be told precisely and without any further obfuscation and delay, by someone with some courage who has the capacity to come into this chamber and face the music, exactly what is in store. We can only conclude that Senator Walsh has finally won and that the 200 programs which he identified as not being justified on social and equity grounds are to be abandoned. The House should well remember the words of Senator Walsh:
I can think of 200 programs that are not justified on social or equity grounds but will not be abandoned because the Government does not have the political courage so to do.

Perhaps the Government suddenly does have some courage. Perhaps we have misunderstood the Government. But if this is a demonstration of its courage, why has the Minister for Social Security demonstrated so publicly for all to see that he is singularly lacking in that very qualification which was so well and eloquently referred to by Senator Walsh-that simple word `courage'. But he is not here. He has left the field. He has run away. There is no alternative explanation. He is now in the vanguard of the retreat from the political scene by the entire Hawke Labor Government. We are seeing only stage one.

We will drive the Government from the treasury benches just as the Australian people will drive many Government members from this House at the next election. They are no longer satisfied to put up for ever with a government of deceit, obfuscation and duplicity; a government whose Ministers do not have the courage to come into the House and face up to the quotations for which they are responsible. If Minister Howe's quotation is wrong, why did not the Minister, in answering two questions today, say so? If the quotation is wrong in terms of the conclusion we have interpreted from it, why did he not have the courage to stand in this House and say so?

This man has been condemned from his own lips. His silence gives us precisely the reason to move this motion. His removal voluntarily-or was it perhaps involuntarily at the request of the Treasurer-from this House demonstrates for all to see that the man is guilty, that he has said more than he ought to have said and that he has now put the Government's hidden agenda on the record. It has a hidden agenda-not just the odd bauble of a couple of million dollars here or there but of some $6 billion. We want to know where the money is coming from. The Australian people want to know where the money is coming from. Until the Government has the courage to tell us, it has no right to ask Australian voters to give it any support.

The Opposition has the hide to come into this place and put forward a proposition accusing us of allegedly having some unfunded tax cuts hovering around in the wings. TALK.START.PARA: —People on low incomes.

—It goes to people on low incomes and it is indexed. We have stated that it will be indexed into the future. The Opposition has given no answer on what it would do about that. Perhaps we are beginning now to understand exactly how that handover of massive resources to the speculative end of the business community-not the productive end of the business community-will be paid for. After the first year, it will be paid for by cuts in the child-care program-a program brought in by this Government and continued. SPEECH.PARA: What a hide the Leader of the Opposition-this man supposedly concerned about child poverty-had to come in here the other day and ask the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a question on that when, sitting in the phalanx of his policies, is a proposition for no indexation of child support after the first year. What did he think Bishop Hollingworth was referring to when he said that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) had produced a set of propositions to really deal with child poverty in this country? What did he think the Australian Council of Social Service was referring to when it congratulated the Government on its performance in the area of child poverty? Yet the Leader of the Opposition had the hide to come in here, ask a question on it and then mosey on out.

Members of the Opposition have a hide to come in here and talk about what they intend to hand back to families as some sort of an achievement, and then ask the Government where its policies are. I will tell the Opposition where the Government's policies are. Government policies have provided a benefit of $25 per week to the typical family example that the Opposition uses in its economic statement. That is what we have done this year; that is our policy. DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hand, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

I am extremely pleased to introduce this Bill, which includes measures providing for the grant of secure title to land to Aboriginal people in the pastoral areas of the Northern Territory. These measures are part of a package agreed to recently by the Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments-an agreement which represents a significant breakthrough in obtaining land justice for Aboriginal people who either live or recently lived on pastoral properties, or whose traditional lands are on pastoral leases. These people have had a long and until now virtually fruitless struggle to obtain secure title to land. Many live on pastoral properties or town camps in conditions equal to those found in Third World countries. It is to the discredit of this nation that such conditions have been tolerated for so long. The provision of secure title to land is essential before these communities can be provided with the infrastructure and facilities necessary to improve their living conditions.

Before describing the measures contained in the Bill, let me review the long history of failed attempts by governments to address this problem. The 1971 report of the Committee to Review the Situation of Aboriginals on Pastoral Properties in the Northern Territory, the so-called Gibb report, recommended the excision from pastoral leases of community living areas. These living areas were envisaged as relatively small areas of land sufficient to meet the basic living needs of an Aboriginal community and to provide that community with a measure of autonomy. In the second report of the Aboriginal Land Rights Commission in April 1974 Justice Woodward again drew attention to this need. Since that time, numerous government committees and independent inquiries have pointed out the urgent need to provide secure title to land to Aboriginal people in pastoral areas. The overriding problem has been that most land in the pastoral areas of the Territory is land leased from the Crown by pastoralists. The Aboriginal Land (Northern Territory) Bill 1975 introduced by the Whitlam Government included provisions to authorise an Aboriginal Land Commissioner to recommend the grant of land on a needs basis in certain areas including land under pastoral lease. In April 1975 the Whitlam Government appointed Mr Justice Ward as interim Aboriginal Land Commissioner to hear needs based claims to land within towns and on pastoral leases. Mr Justice Ward had heard a number of such claims before the events of 11 November 1975 terminated the hearings.

Much to its shame the Fraser Government did not proceed with this proposal. Thus the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976-the Land Rights Act-provides for Aboriginal people to claim only unalienated Crown land or alienated Crown land held by or on behalf of Aboriginal people. As a consequence, several thousand Aboriginal people missed out on the right to acquire title to land in pastoral areas. The Northern Territory Country Liberal Party must also share some of the blame for this. In 1976 the Majority Leader in the Legislative Assembly gave the Commonwealth an assurance that complementary legislation to the Land Rights Act would be introduced. Amongst other things, this legislation would have established a process to handle applications to meet the needs of Aboriginal people in areas where traditional land claims could not be brought. On 4 June 1976, in his second reading speech on the Land Rights Act, the Hon. Ian Viner referred to this assurance:

. . . the Bill gives scope for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly to participate in this most important legislative process in particular . . . in the handling of applications to meet the needs of Aborigines in towns and other areas where traditional claims cannot be established.

I have received assurances from the Leader of the Legislative Assembly that the Assembly is fully prepared to co-operate in the introduction of complementary legislation in these areas which accords with the spirit of this Bill. There will be full consultation with the Territory Assembly and between the Assembly and Aborigines in preparing Territory legislation.

The assurance sought by the Hon. Ian Viner and given by the Majority Leader was not honoured. When this Government came to office in 1983, my predecessor, the Hon. Clyde Holding, initiated discussions with the Northern Territory Government to facilitate the granting of community living areas on pastoral leases. Initially, in 1983, the Northern Territory Government proposed a Community Living Areas Bill. The then Chief Minister, Paul Everingham, acknowledged that for some time the Northern Territory Government had recognised the need for a proper legislative mechanism to enable excisions of community living areas to be achieved more smoothly. At that time only 12 excisions had been granted. In spite of Mr Everingham's acknowledgment the Territory tied this Bill to other legislation alienating land under claim. That legislation was outside its constitutional powers and was opposed by the Commonwealth. Following extensive negotiations by the Commonwealth, in April 1985 the Northern Territory introduced administrative guidelines for excision applications, and undertook to accelerate the process of dealing with those applications. For its part, the Commonwealth undertook to amend the Land Rights Act to limit the right of Aboriginal people to claim stock routes and reserves.

These amendments were enacted in June 1987. However, the Commonwealth said that they would not be proclaimed until arrangements were made for the granting of land to Aboriginal people ineligible to apply for excisions under the Northern Territory's guidelines. The proclamation of the amendments would have resulted in the immediate withdrawal of most land claims over stock routes and reserves from the jurisdiction of the Aboriginal Land Commissioner.

When I first became Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in 1987, I began negotiations with the then Northern Territory Chief Minister, the Hon. Steve Hatton, to try to speed up the very slow progress on the provision of living areas. Unfortunately the working party we established to resolve the delay was later disbanded when the Northern Territory Government withdrew in 1988. By early 1989 it had become clear that the rate of progress in issuing titles under the Northern Territory's living areas guidelines was unsatisfactory. The real losers in the failed attempts by governments to achieve a satisfactory resolution to this problem were of course the Aboriginal people themselves. People who had in many cases seen other Aboriginal people obtain land justice through the land claim processes available under the Land Rights Act were forced to endure years of protracted negotiations with little or no result.

Finally, the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory recommenced negotiations earlier this year. In September the two governments reached an historic understanding when a memorandum of agreement was signed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. This Bill fulfils the Commonwealth's commitment under that agreement. For its part, the Northern Territory has passed legislation which will provide a statutory mechanism to allow certain Aboriginal people to make applications for community living areas on pastoral properties. Land granted under that arrangement will be under freehold title in accordance with Territory law.

I have written to the Chief Minister and expressed my concern that the Northern Territory legislation does not entirely reflect the words of that agreement. This failure has caused some disquiet amongst Aboriginal people. I believe that it is up to the Northern Territory to prove that this disquiet is unfounded. It is one matter which the review process provided for in the agreement will be able to address. Under the terms of the memorandum, the Commonwealth undertook to amend the Land Rights Act as a matter of priority, to provide for the granting of certain parts of existing land claims to stock routes and reserves. At the same time the earlier amendment to the Act limiting claims over stock routes and travelling stock reserves will be proclaimed. The selection of the areas to be granted has been determined after consultation with the Northern Territory.

For the record, a number of these areas relate to the needs of individual communities originally considered by the Gibb Committee, 18 years ago, and by Mr Justice Woodward, 15 years ago. In deciding on the areas to be granted, the Government has been concerned to ensure that the terms of the memorandum of agreement are adhered to. The areas to be granted represent only a small proportion of the land subject to existing claims over stock routes and reserves. The total area of all of the parcels of land described in the Bill, some 2,312 square kilometres, represents only approximately 26 per cent of the total stock route and reserve claims. Looking at the stock route component, the total area of the portions of stock routes to be granted represents approximately only 6 per cent of the total stock route claims. The area of land to be granted is about 0.17 per cent of the total area of the Northern Territory.

The Government has taken steps to ensure that pastoral operations are not unreasonably interfered with by the granting of these areas of land. Where appropriate I have sought relevant undertakings from the Aboriginal claimants for the continued use of station roads, bores or infrastructure by the pastoral lessees. In some instances, the areas have been amended to exclude access corridors or areas of particular concern to pastoralists or the Northern Territory.

Before I go into the detail of the undertakings that have been given, or the land which has been given up by claimants, I want to make two general observations. Firstly, these undertakings are really about sharing the country and the resources. In acceding to my requests for undertakings, the Aboriginal claimants have again demonstrated a willingness to share their land with pastoral operations. This continued willingness to share, and to compromise, is a real tribute to the Aboriginal people. Secondly, where possible, every effort has been made to resolve issues of particular concern raised with me by the Northern Territory by a letter of 25 September 1989. However, I wish to express my disappointment that the Northern Territory has not continued to inform me or officers of my Department of its concerns in relation to the areas to be scheduled as consultations have progressed. While Aboriginal people have remained willing to compromise, the Northern Territory has again shown a disinclination to consider realistically how detrimental issues might be resolved.

Once again, it seems that it is the Aboriginal people who are expected to make all the compromises, and I want to detail now the undertakings they have given. Perhaps the most important undertaking in respect of continuing pastoral operations relates to continued access to water resources. Claimants for the areas at Ammaroo, Alice Well, Black Tank Bore (on Bond Springs), Finke, Mount Peachy (on Maryvale), Henbury/Orange Creek, Mount Kathleen (on Loves Creek) and Undoolya Bore and Williams Bore (on Undoolya) have given undertakings to share access to bores with pastoralists.

In order that pastoral operations will not be inconvenienced by access problems, the claimants for areas at Ammaroo, Ranken River, Undoolya Bore, Forster Range (on Stirling), Mount Peachy, Henbury/Orange Creek and Mount Kathleen have given undertakings relating to the continued use of station roads which may cross the areas to be granted by the pastoralists concerned. Where there appears to be major station infrastructure situated on reserves, at Ammaroo, Mount Peachy and Ooratippra, claimants have undertaken to allow continued access by pastoralists to that infrastructure. As well, an undertaking has been given for the continued access across a stock route for cattle operations at Lorne Creek.

Undertakings have also been given relating to allowing the construction of a water pipeline through Undoolya Bore, the continued use of areas at Mount Solitaire (on Hamilton Downs) by the CSIRO, the grant of easements for the gas pipeline at Birdum (the Jommet Block) and at Elliott, and for the continuation for a reasonable period of a grazing licence affecting part of the land at Birdum. The specifics of the undertakings which have been given will be discussed with the lessees of the relevant pastoral properties. I also put on notice that I will consider any requests for further undertakings which may be put to me by affected pastoralists or the Northern Territory Government.

In the course of my consultations with the Northern Territory Government, four areas, previously identified, have been excluded from this scheduling process because, in terms of the memorandum of agreement, agreement had been reached that the claimants' needs could be satisfactorily met by a grant under Northern Territory title of a portion of stock route and an adjacent excision.

I have also agreed to amend the descriptions of some of the areas to be granted to take into account particular concerns expressed to me by the Northern Territory. In particular, I ask honourable members to note the following examples. The southern boundary of the area to be granted in the Birdum locality has been amended to provide a greater distance between the area and the town of Larrimah. The south-east section of approximately 19 hectares of the area at Newcastle Waters has been excluded from the scheduling process because the claimants recognised the importance of that area in terms of the water needs of the town and surrounding district. In accordance with concerns raised by the Northern Territory, an area used for cattle yards and a dip at Elliott has been excluded from the area to be scheduled. At Finke, the claimants have given up most of the two stock route portions previously included in this area, limiting scheduling to a small section of stock route only. At Henbury/Orange Creek, the original claim was for a length of a stock route cutting across two properties. The claimants have agreed to the granting of four separate portions, representing a reduction of more than 50 per cent of the original claim. Claimants have agreed to the amendment of the southern boundary of the area to be scheduled at the 16 Mile (Bond Springs), at the request of the pastoralist, to provide an access corridor for cattle operations. As well, the area containing the airstrip used by the Alice Springs Gliding Club has been excluded from scheduling.

The conclusion of the agreement between the two governments and the action to be taken because of it finally provide some certainty for Aboriginal people who have been living in these appalling conditions for so many years. It is my hope that living conditions for these people can now be quickly improved.

I turn now to the other provisions contained in this Bill. In 1987 complex new provisions streamlining processes relating to mineral exploration and mining on Aboriginal land were included in the Act. I am now introducing a number of measures to fine-tune those new provisions. Currently, the new exploration and mining provisions do not apply to the Coronation Hill project area and the remainder of the Kakadu conservation zone. The amendments remove this anomaly by providing for the new provisions to apply to these areas. Other amendments to the exploration and mining provisions will allow for an agreement, entered into in relation to exploration, to continue after the end of exploration activity. This will allow for, among other things, rehabilitation of the land to be completed.

There are special provisions relating to the eastern areas on Groote Eylandt and the Coronation Hill project area. These provisions will provide that, where land either is, or becomes, Aboriginal land, exploration licences can be issued without the Land Council's consent. However, a terms and conditions agreement would be required to be entered into. The issue of mining interests on these areas will also be subject to a terms and conditions agreement. I wish to make it clear that this provision will only affect Coronation Hill if and when it becomes Aboriginal land. I expressly state this, as the intended effect of this provision has been misrepresented.

In relation to the payment of mining royalty equivalents into the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account, subsection 63 (3) of the Act is dependent for its operation on the provisions of the former Mining Act of the Northern Territory. However, the Mineral Royalty Act now sets the amount of mining royalties for hard rock minerals and has changed the system from an ad valorem to a profits based royalty system. Subsection 63 (3) will be amended so that it can now function within the new royalty regime operating in the Northern Territory.

There is also a provision to allow Aboriginal people to have access over alienated land where that is necessary for access to their land described in the schedule. There is a provision which will allow for the modification by regulation of the boundaries of areas granted under the new parts to schedule 1. This power is provided to allow for minor correction of descriptions of the land where further survey or other evidence suggests that the boundaries have not been accurately described. The provision is not intended to permit major changes to the area of land to be granted and the power will not be available after the land has actually been granted. There are a number of other amendments of a miscellaneous nature which are more particularly set out in the Bill and the explanatory memorandum.

This Bill, together with the yet to be enacted Northern Territory legislation, provides some measure of justice for deprived groups of Aboriginal people which is long overdue. I regard these proposals to provide land for Aboriginal people as one of the most important achievements in my time as Minister. I wish to thank the Prime Minister and my party colleagues for their support and assistance throughout this process and also to express my appreciation to the officers of both the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Northern Territory Government and officers of the Northern and Central Land Councils. I hope this agreement heralds a new era of cooperation between our governments which can only lead to benefits for Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Territorians. I commend the Bill to the House, and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Smith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —During debate last night on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill I pointed out that the Government was not fair dinkum in respect of this legislation. The major purpose of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) is to exempt those paper products made exclusively from recycled paper.

SPEECH.PARA: I claim that the Government is not fair dinkum in bringing forward this proposition, and I do so for two reasons. Firstly, the total amount of revenue forgone by the Government in respect of this measure will amount, in the Government's own estimation, to less than $500,000 in a full year. So, for the Government to bring forward a proposition which in its own estimation will encourage the recycling of paper but will cost the Government in sales tax revenue forgone less than $500,000 in a full year is simply not fair dinkum. Secondly, the Government is not being fair dinkum in encouraging the recycling of paper because the sales tax exemption will apply only if all the paper in the product has been manufactured from recycled paper. That is simply not possible and I will give technical reasons why in a few minutes. It is my claim, as I said in my contribution last night, that this legislation is brought forward only as a sop to the conservation movement and in the hope that the Australian Labor Party will attract the radical conservation movement.

During debate last night the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) came into the House with a bundle of envelopes and claimed that envelopes could be produced from recycled paper. In a moment I will explain the technical reason why that is not possible and point out in that explanation why this legislation is such a sop. As I said, I will explain why it is technically not feasible to achieve the Government's aim by bringing forward this sales tax exemption legislation. First, I will tell the House of my qualifications. During an earlier part of my career I worked for over six years in a paper manufacturing plant and, therefore, I claim to have more technical expertise in the production of paper than any other member in this House.

The honourable member for Dunkley claimed that envelopes could be made from recycled paper. Technically, that is not possible. One of the major specifications for an envelope is high tensile strength. In other words, the envelopes should be strong enough to stand up to the buffeting to which they are subjected during their life cycle. That is a major specification. If that is not the case, the paper in the envelopes will simply break down under the heavy buffeting to which they are subjected and will tear apart, and their contents will be laid open. Obviously that is unacceptable when looking at the specifications for an envelope.

Let me explain why recycled paper cannot produce the high tensile strength that is a necessary specification for envelopes or, for that matter, for many other paper products. During the pulping process it is necessary to separate the fibres of the wood product, but tensile strength is obtained by having the fibres bind themselves together. That binding together is what produces the tensile strength. During the pulping process the fibres themselves are damaged, and that damage reduces their capacity to bind themselves together. Therefore, the more pulping the fibres are subjected to, the less capacity the fibres have to bind together. The damage to the fibres can be minimised during the initial pulping process so that we can still produce paper that has high tensile strength and the specifications required by end users. However, the more pulping the fibres are subjected to, the less capacity they have to bind themselves together and, therefore, the less tensile strength there is in the end product.

The tensile strength of an envelope produced in the binding process using only recycled paper-in other words, paper that has gone through the pulping process once, twice or repeatedly-would be so low that the thickness of the envelope would have to be three to four times greater than the envelopes we have at present. In other words, they would be like a package and not like an envelope. If they were not, they would simply fall to pieces. The same applies to any sheet of paper, be it newsprint or typing paper, produced using only recycled paper. Because of that technical requirement, a proportion of recycled fibre is mixed with new fibre in the manufacturing process. Therefore, we can use recycled fibre in the manufacturing process but only if it is combined with new fibre, new wood product, and still produce a high tensile strength product.

That is what happens. In fact, it happens in respect of over 50 per cent of the paper that is produced in Australia. Fifty per cent of all paper produced in Australia goes back into the recycling or manufacturing process. That is happening now. However, it is not technically possible, because of the technical requirements of the paper product itself, to produce in any great quantity a product that is made wholly from recycled paper. That is why I claim that this measure is nothing more than a sop to the conservation movement, and the Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sham.

—It is a sham, as my colleague says. As I said to the House last night, the only paper products I can think of that are made wholly from recycled paper and from nothing else are, firstly, egg cartons and, secondly, household insulation. The Government is offering a so-called sales tax exemption and claiming that it is part of its environmental package, but it applies to only a very small range of products. Obviously it will cost the Government in tax revenue forgone less than $500,000 in a full year. I claim that at present over 50 per cent of all the paper produced in Australia goes back into recycled paper. Much of it is being used in downgrade quality products such as cardboard where high tensile strength is not a major specification. Much of it goes into the manufacture of cardboard, but it is being recycled and going back into product. Over 50 per cent is not going back into the recycling process. If the Government were fair dinkum about wanting to get that other 50 per cent back into the recycling process and therefore making better use of the resources available in Australia it would try to encourage more of the paper product to be collected and brought back into the recycling process. The other 50 per cent that is not presently going into recycling ends up on the tip. Somewhere in Australia it ends up on a tip to be burnt.

SPEECH.PARA: As I pointed out to the House last night, there are many charitable organisations in Australia that will collect paper for recycling as a method of raising funds. Organisations such as the Salvation Army, the St Vincent de Paul Society, the Boy Scouts, the Girl Guides Association of Australia and many of the sheltered workshops collect paper for recycling. Much more would be collected if it were possible to get that back into the system. The major inhibiting factor is not the capacity or the preparedness of those charitable organisations to collect paper for recycling, nor is it the preparedness of the Australian people to offer that paper for recycling. The major inhibiting factor is not the sales tax that may be applied to a product that is manufactured from recycled paper but the cost of transporting that recycled paper from the point of collection to the point of manufacture. In many cases the cost of transporting that product from the point of collection to the point of manufacture is greater than the value of the product itself. It is because of the transport costs that a considerable quantity of raw material is not collected for recycling.

If my friends on the other side of the House were fair dinkum about encouraging more paper to go into the recycling process rather than coming forward with a sop of a Bill such as is produced here-a sham of a Bill, as my colleague has described it-they would come forward with a fair dinkum proposal that would reduce the cost of transporting goods in Australia. That would be a far more effective way of encouraging the better use of resources in Australia. As I said to the House last night, not only is the potential for recycling products and resources being inhibited because of the cost of transport but also, naturally, it is having a much greater and broader effect across the whole of the manufacturing and productive industries in Australia.

I do not want to take up any more time of the House. I charge the Government with not being fair dinkum with this measure. Trying to make better use of our resources and to have more material reused and recycled in Australia is a laudable objective, but I do not believe that the Government is fair dinkum in bringing forward this measure because the effect of it will apply only to those products that use recycled paper in the manufacturing process. The range of products made from such a procedure is so limited that it simply will not have the widespread effect it should have. On that basis I hope that the Government will take this Bill back and redraft it to have a far wider effect and to genuinely encourage the recycling of not only paper products but also, many other products that have the potential for recycling.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to support the second reading of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill and to oppose the amendment. I have heard the comments made by my colleague the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) and I want to deal later with a couple of issues he addressed. They concerned application, and I wish to make a couple of suggestions there.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to focus on some other aspects of the legislation. There are two that I find particularly attractive. The first one relates to this change in the threshold tax level for small manufacturers. What has happened is that the Government has decided to raise the threshold tax level for small manufacturers from $12,000 to $50,000. The lifting of the tax threshold means that those small manufacturers will be exempt from paying tax. That is a very sensible move. It is one that I know many small businesses in my area in the Osborne Park and Balcatta business centre welcome because it deals specifically with concerns that they have raised with me.

This lifting of the tax threshold is very important. I can deal in specific terms with what it would mean but one clear aspect is that it minimises some tax and record keeping obligations for manufacturers, aside from the improved market position of having that exemption threshold raised. That is very sensible. I might add, incidentally, in the context of this debate that this sort of move in responding to the community is one that we have tried to pursue in relation to a number of tax matters.

The other aspect of this legislation that I want to talk about is the question of goods that are being used by a subcontractor when that subcontractor is working specifically for a manufacturer. Quite clearly, the intention is not to impose a sales tax until a good is in its final state of reaching the marketplace. Quite clearly, if a subcontractor is working for a major manufacturer-again, I have many major manufacturers in my electorate of Stirling-it would be silly to impose a tax upon materials that are being used in that factory when those materials are not end products, they are merely transitional products. If we think about it in terms of the operation of a factory when a subcontractor is called in to do particular work-whether it be insulation work, electrical work, air conditioning or other activities that are going on in the factory-to impose a sales tax when that work is specifically going towards activities within the factory is a quite unusual arrangement. This is a more sensible arrangement because it means that a manufacturer can now employ a subcontractor provided-I give this qualification-that all of those goods are being used in that manufacturer's activity.

We have to be careful about the question of loopholes here. It is important to emphasise to people who might be listening to this debate that there is the requirement that those materials being used are wholly for the work carried out within the factory. At one stage I was working for CSR Ltd, and I was interested in the number of small subcontractors who were doing maintenance and repair work for CSR. The application of this provision to them is quite significant, as it is for many manufacturers. I would add the qualification that it is important that goods that are being used are used wholly within that maintenance process-if I can use that term-or management process of the factory and that there are no loopholes in that. There are appropriate record-keeping and tracing arrangements to ensure that the legislation will be adhered to.

Those two points together represent a significant gain for small and medium businesses. I believe that they are important reforms in the context of this Government. When we look at the behaviour of business and the impact that tax can have upon business, I have a concern that business is often weighed down with excessive record keeping and excessive complications in the tax law. We have to have a long term policy of trying to minimise the amount of record keeping and the application of tax law to small business. We can do that only if we remove some of the anomalies and the difficulties in tax application. There are two examples that I can think of. We can go down that track of improving the application and administration of tax law only if we also get cooperation and compliance with tax law. Unfortunately, in the past there was a tendency to try to avoid application of tax law, but I believe that through sensible administration of tax law we have a much higher rate of compliance. I could talk about the prescribed payments system but that is outside this legislation. In fact, it would be foreshadowing something that we may well be dealing with in the House shortly. It is important to say that when we improve the compliance level in tax law, we can begin to minimise the application and the record keeping requirements. But one has to precede the other. It is important to emphasise that.

I have many debates with business people about tax laws and I say to them, `I agree with you that, in terms of the efficient operation of business, it is important to minimise the amount of record keeping required and it is also important to minimise the incidence of tax law to the extent to which it may interfere with the productive activity of business. But you can only do that if you are assured on behalf of the general public that there is compliance with tax laws. Once you are assured of that, you can proceed to minimise the applications'.

The whole thrust of this Government's deregulation strategy has been to try to do those things sensibly. It will always be a matter for judgment, and it will always be a matter for professional advice from the Taxation Office and also from accountants and business people. In the context of this debate, I would say that this Government is aware of that and is aware of the general role that the Government can play. These two elements in relation to this sales tax amendment are very important.

Let me move to the other matter, which was being dealt with by the honourable member for Lyons, and that is the question of sales tax exemption on recycled paper. I heard what the honourable member for Lyons said about the tensile strength of paper and about the difference between original paper and recycled paper. At the outset, I make the observation that it is possible to use recycled paper products in high volume. The honourable member for Lyons referred to egg carton and cardboard manufacture. I set those aside because there is agreement on them.

The letterheads used in my office are made from 100 per cent recycled paper. The quality is good and the tensile strength is sufficient for it to go through the rollers of a photocopier where it is stretched. It is reasonably good paper. I am not unhappy with it. In fact, many of my electors have said that they are pleased I am using recycled paper. I take the point of the honourable member for Lyons that envelopes made out of recycled paper are not available in the marketplace, but certainly letterhead quality paper is available. I find it is quite sufficient in terms of standard and I think that members of parliament should be setting the standards for the community by saying that we, too, can play a part.

There has been a big change, a sea change, concerning this notion of environmental decay and public concern about the environment. Governments are responding to that change. A number of us have been aware for a long time about the importance of environmental management. There will not be a revolution overnight about the change in the treatment of recycled paper. That is understood. Very clearly there will be a continuing market demand for fine, white paper products. That is understood in this place. That is all right provided people understand the cost of those white paper products. We know that, in this legislation, we are making the right sort of decision. It would be foolish to stand in this place and say that the Government has an environmental policy but that it will not give any incentive to people to use recycled paper. It would be foolish of the Government not to offer incentives, and that is what this legislation is about.

I repeat that people can use recycled paper products. I am already doing so. Rather than receiving criticism from the electorate, I have had praise because I am doing the sensible thing. I admit that, for some products currently in use, the recycled materials are not of sufficiently high quality or there is insufficient market demand for such a recycled product. But we have to start somewhere and the Government is starting with this legislation.

The honourable member for Lyons made some sensible comments about transport. That raises another issue. As governments-the Federal Government, the State governments, and local government-we need to look at how we can assist in the recycling process. One good example is the recycling of freon gas which is used in car air-conditioners and refrigerators. The Government must provide tax incentives for people, both manufacturers and consumers, who choose to use recycled freon gas. It is a great shame that when a refrigerator has come to the end of its useful life and the seals on the door have perished and the handle has broken off, the freon gas is not retained. People dispose of old refrigerators and the freon gas is emitted into the atmosphere when the refrigerator is crushed up. The Government should be looking at providing an incentive for people to collect the freon gas and for consumers who use recycled freon gas.

The Government should be providing an incentive to manufacturers to protect a car air-conditioning unit so that, in front end collisions, the car air-conditioning plant does not fracture. It is alarming, when driving along a street, to see signs reading, `Top up your air-conditioning unit'. That means that freon gas has been emitted into the atmosphere either because the seals on the air-conditioning unit are loose or the pipes have been fractured in small collisions. I come from a State where 40 degrees centigrade is common in the summer months and people require air-conditioning. Manufacturers and motorists should consider the price being paid for air-conditioned comfort. I speak in terms not of the current market price but of the real social price. That matter should be addressed. Apart from the actual purchasing price, the social costs are that there is not in place an efficient and economically sensible recycling arrangement, and the manufacturing system does not protect the car air-conditioning unit properly. The Government can move in that direction but, very often, to do it, governments have to provide a tax incentive and the education process, which is clearly what we are debating.

They are simply examples of what can be done if we are determined enough to go down that track. Governments, particularly the Federal Government, must show that they are serious about the environment and about recycling. What better way is there than starting with paper products which are commonly used? A good deal could be done in terms of encouraging the effective recycling of freon gas used in car air-conditioners and refrigerators. A good deal could be done by offering tax incentives to those who choose to recycle and choose to use recycled products. I refer to the manufacturer and wholesaler as well as the consumer. This legislation gives a lead by removing sales tax on recycled paper.

I repeat that this product can be used. My letterheads in my electorate office are made from recycled paper. I am very happy with the product. It is not the fine, white paper that people press for in certain circumstances. But why should we let advertisers determine our destiny as we often do? Quite often we allow the advertisers to tell us that we should not use paper unless it is absolutely white. I refute that claim out of hand because we have to consider the cost of producing fine white paper. When I look round the chamber, it is a great source of dismay to me to see the quantity of paper wasted. It is nice to know that much of it is being recycled. It is very fine paper that is being used.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you would stop we would save a bit of paper.

—I do not condemn people for using that quality of paper because the market expects it. In reply to the remark about Hansard, it has been my view since Parliament moved to this building that the chamber should become largely paper free. SPEECH.PARA: Today I have walked in with the second reading speeches on three Bills and the Budget statements, which would also be on line because they are incorporated in Hansard.
