I say to my colleagues in the Parliament that there is a lot of interest in doing something about calling up information on screen. We could easily do that. It would make a great difference, and it would support the general thrust of this legislation.

I am pleased that this legislation is in place. But what does it mean in terms of what is happening locally? I heard the honourable member for Lyons say something about transport costs. One of the difficulties at the moment is that we have a bottleneck. The amount of public offering of recycled paper is considerable. I hope that colleagues will do what we do in my office, that is, shred most of our material and try to package it ready for collection for recycling. The difficulty is that the amount of recycled paper being provided is exceeding the current demand for it, which is why it is important to remove the sales tax. Incidentally, I give out information to my local community. I compliment my local authority, the Stirling City Council, which provides a lot of information on where newspapers can be recycled. It also has a house to house collection service for recycled paper. It plays a substantial role for which it is to be commended. The City of Stirling has recycling locations in Balcatta, Carine, Doubleview, Innaloo, Joondanna, Maylands, Osborne Park, Scarborough, another in Scarborough and Yokine. It also supports a house to house collection service; it is done by the Australian Mutual Provident Society but the Council supports that thrust. So a lot is happening.

I have heard the remarks of colleagues in this debate. We have to work this issue through. It is not the sort of issue on which we should hammer away as in a party political debate. We are talking about a matter on which we have shown a sensible initiative in removing the sales tax. I point out to colleagues that they can use recycled paper products; I currently do. I say to the community in general, `For goodness sake, do not be confused by the advertisers. We have to reject the same line that they use in relation to toilet paper-that if it is not very white it is not very good.' Certain advertisers have a clear interest in creating a market expectation. If we can get the public to think differently, I am sure we can get them to increase their demand for recycled products. This legislation will play its part. Accordingly, I am pleased to support the legislation and to oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), in this debate I want to address my remarks to the issue of the sales tax exemption for recycled paper. Other speakers from this side of the House have made it clear that the coalition supports this initiative by the Government in the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2). We do so with a sense of pride really because over a year ago we announced the coalition's environment policy in which we proposed precisely this measure. It has taken the Government a year to pick up the initiative from this side of the House. I am glad that it has picked it up and I make no partisan comment about that. When the Opposition makes constructive suggestions and the Government takes them up, we see one further aspect of our parliamentary system truly working, and working well.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this Government initiative came out of the environment statement from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 20 July 1989. I must say that that statement and many of the initiatives in it, including this one, seem to have more to do with winning the preferences of the Green movement at the forthcoming Federal election than with any broader commitment to improving our environment. I give an example of where the Government on the one hand is reducing, or getting rid of, the sales tax on recycled paper but on the other hand is taking away similar sorts of sales tax exemptions for other environmentally friendly initiatives. I received a letter recently from Mr Brian Esselbach, the President of the South Australian Soft Drink Association Inc, who drew my attention to the fact that since 1 September the Federal Government has removed an exemption which encouraged the use of refillable bottles by beverage manufacturers. The South Australian Soft Drink Association has pointed out that previously the cost of recovering and refilling the bottle designed for multifilling was exempt from the calculation for sales tax on the product. The Government has taken away that exemption. It is interesting to note that the cost to a big soft drink manufacturer such as Coca-Cola Bottlers in Adelaide is about $400,000 a year. That initiative discourages the practice of recycling bottles-not paper in this case. That does not sit comfortably with this initiative by the Government to take away the sales tax on recycled paper.

The reason is that the issue of recycling bottles has apparently had a lesser public profile than the issue of recycling paper. If that is the case, and if that is the only basis for a government making one decision heading in one direction and another decision heading in another direction, any fair-minded person-not just a party politician-would conclude that the initiative of the Government is a cynical one. I wish that governments generally, especially the Federal Government, would be more sincere in their approach to environmental issues, look at the merits and the demerits of different propositions and try to work out what are the best social and economic answers to the conundrums with which we are faced.

As honourable members will know, many emotional arguments are put forward-I have heard many an emotional argument put forward in this debate-in favour of certain so-called environmentally friendly initiatives without very much serious analysis of the social and economic benefits and disbenefits of those initiatives. We need to establish first and foremost in this debate whether the recycling of paper is worth while. Obviously, to some extent the recycling of paper is deemed to be worth while because a fair amount of it takes place in Australia already. In other words, there is an existing economic incentive to recycle some paper. What the Government is proposing in this legislation is that that economic incentive, or the economic circumstances that currently exist, should be enhanced by a sales tax exemption to act as a further incentive to encourage the practice of recycling paper.

I suppose the basic argument here is that the optimum level of recycling occurs where the net social benefit is maximised. That must be axiomatic. The maximisation of the net social benefit does not necessarily occur at the same point as the greatest degree of profitability that can occur for industry through a recycling operation. What I am really saying is that industry costs perhaps do not reflect all social costs. That is one of the arguments I often use in the whole environmental debate. Our advanced Western capitalist economy works basically on the basis of maximising benefits and minimising costs through the operation of the market system, which is as it should be, but in some areas, particularly in the areas of the environment, social costs are not properly measured and incorporated into the market mechanism. Where those social costs are not properly incorporated, there is a basis for government taking some action, such as the action being taken here in providing what by some arguments is an unlevel playing field, giving recycled paper an exemption when such exemption does not exist for other sorts of paper.

I mentioned earlier that we have to ask ourselves whether recycling of paper is fundamentally a good thing. In other words, overall, will the social advantages as well as the economic advantages of recycling paper outweigh the costs? I suggest that there are about five different reasons why the recycling of paper is on balance a positive initiative, although some negatives come out of it. First of all, it is argued that we will save forest resources by recycling paper. That must surely be the case. That may not matter if those forests are not native forests, and if they are plantations, they can simply be replanted after the wood has been used. But, of course, some very severe long-term environmental costs occur to society through the depletion of native forests. Only between 15 and 20 per cent of paper manufactured in Australia-much of our paper is actually imported-comes from native forests, so between 80 and 85 per cent comes from plantations.

But the depletion of those native forests I think imposes a very high social cost which is not easy to measure in simple financial terms. It imposes costs on fauna, on water catchment areas and on soils because of the soil degradation that may occur. It depends how responsible forestry practices are. The depletion of native forests also imposes an aesthetic cost because the loss of those forests leads to a loss of some natural beauty. So, clearly, a cost is involved in depleting native forests which are used for the production of paper.

The second argument in favour of recycling is that through recycling we can avoid some of the water pollution which occurs from the processing of wood in order to create paper. The third advantage is that we can achieve lower energy costs through recycling. Clearly through the achievement of lower energy costs we are moving towards maximising economic efficiency. Fourthly, through the practice of recycling we can avoid the disposal costs of wastepaper, and I will come back to that issue a bit later. Finally, through the practice of recycling we can make a contribution to improving Australia's trade balance. After all, much of the paper that is currently used in Australia is imported. If we can recycle paper rather than have greater imports being drawn into the country, there is an obvious advantage to the trade balance. Australia also exports some waste paper which is used for recycling purposes. So maybe another way we can help to contribute towards our trade balance is by expanding that sort of operation.

Let us not forget, though, that through the process of recycling paper there are some disbenefits. The issue of waste paper collection costs is not one that should be ignored. Substantial costs are involved with the collection of waste paper and, at the moment, those costs are not properly recognised in our pricing structure. But collection does impose substantial costs and therefore a redistribution of scarce economic resources away from some sectors of the economy. We should not overlook that. Also, the practice of recycling involves some water pollution, just as the manufacture of ordinary paper involves some pollution of waterways. In particular, the process of de-inking can seriously contribute to water pollution.

So when we look at the whole practice of the recycling of paper we see that there are costs and there are benefits. My argument today is that those costs and benefits need to be reflected properly in the market price of these operations. At present many particular costs are not properly reflected in the market price that we charge for paper.

Let us just have a look at three things that are not properly included in the market price. We do not include the depletion of forest resources-in particular, native forest resources-and I have mentioned already some of the costs associated with that. We do not include the full cost of water pollution that comes about from the manufacture of paper. For example, we do not properly recover from the manufacturer the costs that the manufacturer imposes, for example, on downstream water users. The cost of cleaning up that pollution is generally borne by the broader community and not by the polluter himself; therefore, that cost is not reflected in the costs for the purchaser of ordinary, newly created paper.

Finally, we do not reflect properly the disposal costs of waste paper in our society. For many people just throwing away paper is really costless. I suppose everybody thinks that the throwing away of paper is costless. In reality, it is not costless because thousands upon thousands of tonnes of paper have to be disposed of every day. Disposing of that paper is a very expensive business and the general taxpayer ends up picking up the bill. In the case of local government, the ratepayer might well be the person who ends up picking up the very hefty bill for the disposal of that waste paper. So in the practice of purchasing ordinary new paper, as distinct from recycled paper, those three costs are not included. In a sense, people are getting non-recycled paper-new paper, if you like-on the cheap because the cost of forest resources, the cost of water pollution and the cost of the disposal of waste paper are simply not included in that process.

It is interesting to see that the Australian Environment Council in its report of, I think, last year picked up similar points to these. It recommended what I thought were some fairly radical solutions to these problems which, in a sense, would have created a level playing field for the practice of recycling paper-a level playing field brought about by incorporating costs which are currently not incorporated in the price of new paper. It argued for a marriage of economic rationalism and environmental conservation. I think a lot more work needs to be done on that proposition and a lot more thought needs to be given to it by honourable members on both sides of this Parliament. But the Australian Environment Council argued for a very respectable proposition-that we ought to move more in the direction of the user and the polluter paying. I think in many respects I have probably covered how that could work in the context of the recycling of paper as against the use of new paper.

One of the difficulties that the Australian Environment Council has alerted us all to is the difficulty of defining the exact value of the environment, particularly if we are to assess in some way the costs associated with the depletion of native forest resources. I think that will be one of the important challenges that the Resource Assessment Commission will have to pick up very soon because those issues arise in many environmental debates, not just in the area of the use of paper. Some formula will have to be found in the years ahead for defining the exact value of environmental resources, of natural resources. I have been interested to see that in the United Kingdom the new British Secretary of State for the Environment has commissioned some work on that exact issue. I think here in Australia we ought to do a lot more work than we are doing on that matter.

The Government has actually taken a very arbitrary measure-it is only a notional measure-of the value of the environment and the costs, if you like, to the environment of using new paper. I suppose that we can measure the arbitrary value that the Government has taken, in terms of lost revenue, through this measure. I apologise for not knowing precisely what that figure is. It is probably in the legislation somewhere, but I have forgotten to look it up. But the Government has gone for the sales tax solution as an alternative; a very rough and ready, arbitrary, and economically irrational alternative. Consequently, different ways of encouraging the practice of recycling and different ways of assessing social costs as well as ordinary commercial costs need to be developed by the Resource Assessment Commission and by the Parliament itself.

The Australian Environment Council recommended a number of other ways in which a government could allocate costs fairly arbitrarily. It recommended that the Government could encourage collection schemes for higher quality waste paper. I think there is a great deal to be said for that, although it is easier said than done. Incentives would have to be given to people to provide waste paper for those collection schemes. The honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) pointed out how local government can contribute to that by facilitating collection schemes and perhaps more ought to be done in that area. The Australian Environment Council also recommended that the Government alter its own demand for high quality paper which can be more easily recycled than a low quality product. Again, that is something that the Government itself needs to examine much more carefully.

I think this piece of legislation can be commended. It takes up an initiative of the Opposition and I am very glad that the Government has done that. But I think a great deal more work needs to be done on relating economic rationalism to conservation. The recycling of paper is a perfectly good example of this. I must say that I am getting sick and tired of hearing people in the community in general-certainly not just politicians-saying that recycling is just a good thing. Without looking at all the costs involved, they say it is a good thing and that is the end of the debate. As a matter of fact, that reflects something that I know the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) would agree with-that we are a fairly scientifically illiterate society. People are not prepared to try to understand the true costs and true benefits probably because they have not been given the opportunities to learn those things through our education system. The declining number of people taking up science in schools and tertiary institutions is only compounding the problem of a scientifically illiterate society. If I, for that matter, were a little more literate scientifically, I would have a much greater capacity to understand the degree to which we should move towards the recycling of paper and thousands upon thousands of other similar things.

In conclusion, I would like to make the same point that I made at the beginning of my speech, that I think this piece of legislation has been introduced only for political purposes. It is not part of a broader contemplation of ways of improving our environment because it bears no rational relationship to other things that the Government has done. If, on the one hand, the Government can discourage, through changes to sales tax, the use of refillable bottles and, on the other hand, encourage the recycling of paper in another piece of legislation, it is clearly not thinking things through properly and in a coherent way. I hope in the months and years ahead that we will see the new Peacock Government and State governments contemplating these matters in a coherent and rational way, that we will work towards trying to establish true costs, including environmental costs, and that we will ensure through economically rational practices that we are able to conserve our environment better than we can at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept part of the hypothesis advanced by the honourable member for Mayo that there is a need for additional work to be undertaken by government in this whole area of recycling. I am not sure that a more rational economic system is the way to go. But I concede that more needs to be done in this area if the community is to have a better understanding of the relative costs and merits of using recycled products as against new products.

Put simply, the legislation gives effect to the commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the July environment statement to reduce the rate of sales tax on recycled paper from 20 per cent to zero. I must say that that exceedingly comprehensive environment statement traversed a whole range of environmental matters that affect the way in which we live and work in Australia. It covered matters such as land care programs and soil conservation, which we describe as the biggest single problem facing Australia in the 1990s. The statement recommended, among other things, a decade of land care. I know that that aspect of the statement has been very warmly welcomed in my electorate of Bendigo.

I should say that the decision to eliminate sales tax on 100 per cent recycled paper has also been very warmly greeted in my electorate of Bendigo. Over the last few months I have had a large number of representations from schools in my electorate inquiring about this policy commitment and asking when it will come into effect. Over the years I have taken a great deal of interest in the work of Sandhurst Enterprises, a local industry which is now the largest recycler of waste products in Bendigo. This firm is now recycling in excess of 20 tonnes of waste paper a year. I am very pleased to see the way in which it has expanded and the many employment opportunities in Bendigo that have been created.

I think there has been a change in the consumer ethic in the community. Generally, consumers are now keen to use a product which can be economically recycled and which, in the longer term, will be better for our environment. There is a greater concern about environmental issues. In that sense, members of this House would note, again with some pleasure, that the largest single mass distribution newspaper in Australia today, Age Pension News, which is sent to every aged pensioner and war veteran in Australia, is now printed on 100 per cent recycled paper. That is very much a step in the right direction. It is still a quality product and the change has been received very well in my electorate. I have received a very positive feedback on the fact that it is printed on recycled paper.

I guess with a lot of speculation around about when the next Federal election will be held in the next eight months, the question--(Quorum formed) I was talking about the impeccable record of this Government in the environment area. I was referring to that part of the legislation which eliminates the 20 per cent sales tax on fully recycled paper. As has been said previously in this debate, the exemption will apply to a wide range of paper products, including writing, drawing or printing paper that is blank, incorporated printed guidelines, a trade mark, logo, letterhead, or similar matter. It will also apply to envelopes. Contrary to the comments made by the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), it is possible to buy envelopes made from recycled paper. Although not many are on the market yet, I understand that more envelopes made from recycled paper will appear in future. Other exemptions in the legislation apply to toilet and facial tissues and paper bags for use by householders and retailers. So it is very sensible legislation.

Before I was interrupted by the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) calling a quorum, I had said that an election is due in the next six or nine months. Over the last few years a number of people have suggested that the Parliament should seriously look at how-to-vote cards. Normally in Federal elections people representing the different political parties stand outside polling booths and hand out how-to-vote cards to everyone who turns up to vote. On average, one how-to-vote card has to be printed for every voter. Therefore, on any election day in Australia 10 million how-to-vote cards are printed and used. I believe that in the next parliament-probably it is not something that can be undertaken in the run-up to the election-an environment committee or select committee of that parliament should carefully examine the role of how-to-vote cards and whether for every general election we need to print up to 10 million of those cards to hand them to people so they know how to vote. In round terms, there are 10 million cards for each political party. Bearing in mind that the major party in Australia, the Australian Labor Party; the minor parties, the Liberal and National parties, and the other parties, the Australian Democrats--

—As the honourable member says, you could build a bridge to Tasmania. —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. A choice has to be made in this area. One could consider printing how-to-vote cards on recycled paper, which is relevant to the legislation before us, or doing away with them altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: My final comment about the exemption of sales tax on recycled paper product is the general one of how it ties into environmental programs. I noticed earlier this week that thousands of people have signed the one world petition. The terms of the petition will be included in Hansard. In my electorate, 380 to 400 people signed the petition in support of the one world campaign. Basically that is a campaign of interested, committed, Australians who are concerned that we ensure that the world is sustainable both economically and environmentally. Obviously, providing incentives for people to consume recycled paper products is an important element of that campaign.

I am pleased to see that the legislation will increase the small manufacturer exemption thresholds of sales tax. That initiative will be of great benefit to my electorate. It will be of particular benefit to a large number of small industries, particularly potteries and craft shops, which are vital to the tourist trade throughout central Victoria and which enjoy such a fine reputation for producing products of real quality. In the past, goods manufactured by small manufacturers were exempt from sales tax only where the manufacturer's average annual sales were $12,000 or less or where the manufacturer's sales tax liability was $250 or less per annum. The legislation before the House will increase the exemption thresholds to $50,000 per annum in average annual sales or $1,000 per annum in sales tax liability. When I was first elected to this Parliament in 1983 I received a number of representations from small potters and craft shops in my electorate which were concerned about that limit. I concede that it has taken some time for an amendment to be made to the Act but I know, from my communications with those people in my electorate, that they very much welcome the changes being introduced in the legislation.

In terms of the sales tax on flavoured milk drinks, over recent months I have received, as the Federal member for Bendigo, a number of representations, particularly from canteen managers. I note that the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), who is in the chamber, indicates that he too has received representations. I suggest that perhaps a national campaign is being organised by a particular group which is inspiring canteen managers and schools to complain about the level of sales tax which applies on flavoured milk. The level of sales tax applying to most flavoured milk products is only 10 per cent. The rate of sales tax applied to most other flavoured, sweetened or coloured non-alcoholic drinks is 20 per cent. The point that needs to be emphasised-I have made it to canteen managers-is that the present sales tax rate of 10 per cent on flavoured milk products is already a concessionary rate. Moreover, the letters that I have received from canteen managers have lauded the nutritional value of milk. What I have also been able to point out to those canteen managers is that because the Government recognises that, whole milk is totally tax-exempt in Australia. No sales tax applies to pure milk which is sold in school canteens or tuck shops.

The Parliament-because this legislation is supported by the Opposition-has a commitment to ensure that young people are not denied access to a nutritious product. No sales tax is payable on a 100 per cent milk product. Sales tax is payable on flavoured milk at only 10 per cent. As I said, that compares with 20 per cent for most other milk products. In this Bill before the House we are reducing the minimum milk content requirement of flavoured milk from 95 per cent to 90 per cent. So the vast majority of flavoured milks on the market will now qualify for that 10 per cent concessional tax rate.

I want to make one last general comment about sales tax. Just before I came to speak in this debate I was presented with a submission from the National Farmers Federation (NFF) in which it proposed the introduction of a broad-based goods and services tax to replace the wholesale sales tax regime. The Federation suggests that it would replace the wholesale sales tax base as its stands at the moment and the whole excise tax base as it stands at the moment. It would also replace customs duties and certain tariffs. If one does the sums in the existing Budget Papers for 1988-89 one finds that about $20 billion of total government revenue of $82 billion-in other words, around one-quarter; $1 in every $4-is raised from these taxes: from sales taxes at the wholesale level, from excise and from customs duties.

The NFF is proposing a broad-based goods and services tax to replace that revenue base of $20 billion. It has said that it thinks the rate would be around 10 per cent, but the calculations I have done suggest that, if $20 billion of the general revenue base were to be replaced with a straight tax on goods and services, the rate would in fact be much closer to 20 per cent than 10 per cent. This would mean that the tax on many goods, and therefore the price, would rise considerably. This is very relevant to this debate as I have been discussing matters such as the tax rate on flavoured milk and recycled paper. Of course, under a broad-based consumption tax-a goods and services tax such as the NFF is proposing-all of those items would be taxed at a rate of around 20 per cent.

The NFF has made a valuable contribution to economic debate but I cannot support its proposal for a broad-based goods and services tax because, on my calculations, it would mean a general rate of around 20 per cent applying to every good and service produced in Australia. That rate is too high. I think the existing wholesale sales tax system we have in place is sensible because it is possible for government to make changes and to change consumption patterns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sales tax is an area of considerable concern in the community. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), made some remarks regarding the sort of burden it imposes. As he said, the Budget Papers reveal that tax collections amount to, if we take into account other fees, nearly $26 billion in various forms of consumption taxes or taxes that are not upfront; I call them taxes by stealth. Of course, I have always been of the view that, whoever is in government, such taxes should be much more easily identified. I would welcome every service station in the country having to advertise fuel at 20c a litre plus tax. This occurs in the United States of America, where consumption tax laws are very explicit. Places such as Disneyland and Disneyworld are at pains to advise the tax component of what is being spent. I am sure it is a great discipline on politicians. The consumption tax area is a mechanism for much larger government spending because it is hidden taxation, particularly as practised in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has moved an amendment to this legislation which simply and quite correctly complains about the massive growth of sales tax under this Government. We are under no illusions at all that the incumbent Treasurer (Mr Keating) is the biggest taxing Treasurer in Australia's history. He has managed to double not only the sales tax-the hidden tax-but all tax collections during his term in office. Tax collections were at about $44 billion in the last Fraser Budget. Of course, they now total nearly $96 billion. It is interesting to note that pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers are now paying $41 billion in taxation. The total tax collections in the last Fraser Budget were about that amount. So under the world's best Treasurer, PAYE taxpayers collectively are paying as much tax-and their numbers certainly have not doubled-as the entire tax system delivered in the last Fraser Budget.

Fortunately, a few aspects of this legislation will slightly reduce tax collections, and I welcome them. The Government followed the initiative of the coalition, which announced prior to the world's greatest environmental statement that it would include in its policy a provision to remove sales tax on recyclable paper. The Government, which was still struggling with this decision, has now followed our initiative and has put it in the world's greatest environmental statement. Recycling is to be encouraged at every level for economic as well as environmental reasons. I would like honourable members to think for a minute, in relation to recycling, of the mix of the economy and the environment that so frequently is either ignored or separated by people. Australians cannot maintain their current standard of living unless they develop environmentally acceptable industries. They have to use the resources available to them.

We now have a stupid situation where this Government still allows the export of woodchip because it has not discovered the means by which that woodchip can be turned into paper, thus providing the community with all its value added benefits. The Government's solution is to put up the barricades and stop the projects that have been offered to us because it does not know how to fix the problems. The argument has raged-other countries have not accepted it-that environmental damage is caused by the current style of kraft paper production. But if we were to accept that damage could be caused, as a country that considers itself to have high levels of technology, we are doing nothing to discover solutions that might make paper pulp manufacture in Australia environmentally acceptable.

Why are we having difficulty discovering solutions? In every Budget this Government has deliberately cut back on the research effort of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). The very group of government activists who could do something about the problem are having their budget cut; scientists are being sacked. What other solution do we have? We can go on recycling paper until someone eventually finds that arsenic levels or something have built up to an unacceptable point and that people's health is at risk. We can also go on exporting woodchips. But this nation, as we all know, cannot survive in that situation. It is amazing that for environmental reasons we continue to export raw materials because we do not have the scientific research to establish environmentally acceptable means of meeting other manufacturing criteria.

We welcome this reduction in sales tax but it is a drop in the ocean in the environmental debate. We deplore a government that is so short of ideas that it has to stop a major pulp paper manufacturing development in Tasmania because it does not know how to fix the problem. I assure the House that we will ensure that resources are available for those sorts of decisions because we have a commitment to productivity. We further have a commitment to prosperity through productivity. That is the vast difference between the Government and the Opposition. The Government has a system that says, `Screw the wages down and we will prove some form of growth or reduction in unit costs'. We say that the means of achieving reduction in unit costs is by an increase in productivity and the associated prosperity that goes with it.

Every area of tax has grown under this Government, as has sales tax. I would like to comment on the fact that this legislation also provides for an allowance before the small manufacturers have to levy sales tax. I use the word `levy' advisedly. Quite clearly the sales tax legislation requires that the manufacturer or the wholesaler is the taxpayer. That is often forgotten. The consumer pays in the end, but in terms of the law it is the responsibility of the manufacturer or wholesaler to pay. This legislation exempts certain manufacturers, but not if their turnover exceeds $1,000 a week-slightly less than that, in fact. That is not a very big manufacturing exercise; in fact, it is minuscule. No adjustment has been made to that level since 1979. It is not as generous as it looks because the $12,000 that was applicable previously would represent about $27,000 today; but it certainly is a help. I think it should have been more generous.

I also wish to speak on how the burden of collecting sales tax is imposed upon small business. As I have just explained, small business is the taxpayer. Small businesses have to pay their tax on the due date, notwithstanding that most times they have not been paid for the goods themselves. I made an impassioned plea to the Treasurer some years ago. He wanted to adjust the tax scales and even them all out at 10, 15 or 20 per cent, whatever the figures were, but in the process pick up $110m. I pointed out that it would be a good opportunity to use that windfall, which was not in his Budget, to extend the time that small business had to pay that sales tax to the Australian Taxation Office. I proposed that, even if it were progressively extended by five or 10 days a year until at least the period in which the small businessman had to pay that tax, it was equivalent to the terms of credit that he extended to his own clients. The small businessman is a tax collector, but under the law he is made a taxpayer; he cannot get out of it.

That raises the second question. The great problem with sales tax for small business is knowing when it has to be collected. The complexity of the legislation is such that we frequently cannot even get an answer from the Tax Office. The Tax Office is in the happy situation of being able to second-guess it. If a person is given advice by the Tax Office and it is wrong, it is tough. It can second-guess the situation and say, `You should have collected it anyway'. Examples have been brought to my attention where businesses have gone broke. Over a period they have continued to sell a product thinking that it was either tax exempt to a certain group, or otherwise not knowing that it was taxable at all, and then the tax inspectors have come in. The amounts outstanding can be quite gigantic. We are talking about 20 per cent of the value of a particular product that might be valued at thousands of dollars. One cannot buy much under $1,000 these days. The amount of money owed is probably in excess of the value of their property and assets, and down the tube they go. It is nearly as bad as the Government's recent decision to dump the new tax collection regime on small corporations by 15 July following the end of the financial year.

If the next speaker from the Australian Labor Party knows anything about small business-I have demonstrated time and again that the Treasurer does not; he claims to have been the manager of a rock band, which only meant that he was the truck driver-he would understand that most small businessmen are unable to extend their stocktake by 15 July, let alone have their affairs in order to calculate and pay their tax. It is a most stupid suggestion and it is doubly stupid simply because the Government had just arrived at a reasonable arrangement; it got away from a single tax point for the year to a point of quarterly payments, which had a much more balancing effect on the money supply. I supported that because it did not have the shock of a single payment. Everything was reasonably balanced, and the Government goes back to a single payment per annum and expects people to be in a position to calculate their tax within 15 days at the end of the financial year. That is fine for companies such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and others with their massive computers and those sorts of things; they can do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has this got to do with it?

—Are Government members getting sensitive about it? But little people have not got those facilities, any more than they have the ability to work out the complexities of the sales tax law. Small businessmen have had great difficulty with this sales tax adjustment.

—I will explain for the benefit of the honourable member who addressed his remarks to the Chair that I did allow the honourable member for Bendigo to go on for a little while. Furthermore, I do not appreciate reflections on the Chair. If the honourable member wants to address the Chair, he might also rise in his place.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think that tax on small business and sales tax are areas of concern. I have taken this opportunity to raise them. I also wanted to mention how difficult sales tax is in many regards. I represent a rural electorate where many of the items that are taxed are exempt in their use in the rural industries, the agricultural industries. I applaud that longstanding decision. Some most remarkable situations have arisen. A constituent of mine wanted to weigh the fleeces of all his sheep for the purpose of improving the efficiency of his flock management. The scales which he wished to use to weigh the fleeces are exempt. They are considered an aid to manufacture. But the computer to which he wished to link it so that this could be an automatic process-this was essential to make it work-was not so considered, and, notwithstanding our representations, we never got anywhere on that matter. Again, it would be of great value if some legislation were brought before the Parliament which addressed the difficulty that smaller businesses in particular have-there are 750,000 of them in Australia-in dealing with such complexities as the sales tax legislation and now the company tax legislation, which many of them will have to deal with as they are incorporated. It is a real problem to me.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I note is that there are to be changes to the requirements for paying tax for some subcontractors. That is to be welcomed. We are not critical of that. I remind the House of the concentrated efforts of the Opposition to stop the Government in its original attack on flavoured milk. It is nice to see the Government being generous at this stage by lowering the tax requirements, but it is a pity it was introduced in the first place. This Government did it, ever chasing revenue. This Government keeps talking about economic management and balancing its Budget. Every bit of it is being done by increasing taxes. I frequently tell audiences that it is just like a wife who considers herself to be a good budgeter because she is able to tell her husband how much money to go out and earn each week. Those sorts of people do not get that opportunity. The Treasurer has just gone on adding to the tax burden of Australians year after year, and he says, `Am I not a wonderful manager?'. He rabbits on in here about capital gains taxes and other matters. He was in it for one reason, and one reason alone-to get more money. He certainly managed to achieve that.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Opposition members are consulting their House of Representatives Standing Orders and books on practice I intend to make some comments about the legislation before the House, which deals with sales tax, an area which is very complex, as you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is an area which requires some consideration by this Parliament. The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), has moved an amendment in relation to this legislation. It is an amendment which is worthy of some consideration. The honourable member for Wentworth has moved that `the House deplores the Government's economic irresponsibility in increasing sales tax revenue by 200 per cent in an ad hoc and distortionary fashion'.

SPEECH.PARA: I have gone to the trouble to dig out the Budget Papers on sales tax. People in the gallery might be aware that the honourable member for Wentworth was the senior economic adviser of the former Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), during the Howard-Fraser years. When one looks through the figures as to the real rates of change in sales tax in the last 10 years, guess in which year there was the greatest real increase? (Quorum formed) I thank the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) very much for calling the quorum and wasting so much of the time of the House. It is a pity that not one member of the National Party has even entered the chamber at this time of night. I ask the Deputy Opposition Whip perhaps to speak with a few of the National Party members to get them into the chamber.

The Opposition has moved an amendment in relation to this legislation, saying that this Government should be condemned for the massive increase in sales tax. Honourable members would be interested to learn in which year there was the greatest increase in sales tax. Guess which year it was? In 1981-82 there was a 22 per cent increase in sales tax. Who was the Treasurer then? It was the honourable member for Bennelong. Who was his main adviser? It was the current shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth. That is the record of the previous Government-a 22 per cent real increase in sales tax revenue in 1981-82 compared to a projected increase for this year, in this Government's most recent Budget, of only 5 per cent. That is the Opposition's record on sales tax.

Some very interesting words are used in this amendment proposed by the Opposition. The Opposition says that it deplores the increase in sales tax in an ad hoc and distortionary fashion. What is the Opposition getting at there? How could one increase sales tax in a manner that is not ad hoc? One could do so by introducing a consumption tax, which, we realise, is the Opposition's hidden agenda. That is the way it would fund all the extravagant promises it is making around the country.

We know that John Elliott wants the Opposition to introduce a consumption tax. We know that Opposition members slugged it out in the smoke-filled rooms of this building as to whether they would have a consumption tax in their policy. We know that the honourable member for Wentworth was arguing for a consumption tax. We know that the main economic advisers of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) were right there behind the honourable member for Wentworth, supporting him, arguing for a consumption tax. It was only the Leader of the National Party (Mr Blunt) and John Stone who, somehow or other, were able to gather the numbers and stop the Opposition advocating a consumption tax in the lead-up to the election.

But what is going to happen after the election? What would happen to the Opposition's policies if it won office? We have had vast experience of the Liberal and National parties. They make extravagant promises as to how they will cut income tax and introduce tax indexation but they never deliver. In fact, they take back what they give within six months to a year. So that is the Opposition's record. It cannot stand by any of its promises on tax. We know that many senior members of the Opposition would like to have a consumption tax in the Opposition's policy now, but if they cannot get that they will take second best. They will ram through a consumption tax if, by chance, they get elected at the next election. I do not think that is good enough for the Australian people. I do not think it is good enough that the Opposition can try to slink into office without telling us where it stands on sales tax and a consumption tax.

This evening I have the pleasure of having a group of children from the Dooralong Public School visit Parliament House. It appears that a class from another primary school is currently in the gallery visiting Parliament House. Perhaps I could let the children in the gallery know that when the students from Dooralong Public School in my electorate took the opportunity to ask me questions about what I do as a member of parliament and what the Government's position is, one of the students said to me, `One of the most important questions I have for you, Mr Lee: is what is the Government doing about the environment?'. That is a very pertinent question. I would not be surprised if a few of the children in the gallery asked similar questions of their local member.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are expressing some interest.

—They are indeed. I was able to explain to the students from Dooralong Public School that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised in July that more than one billion trees will be planted in the next 10 years, which I believe will do a lot to ensure that we have as many trees as possible converting carbon dioxide into oxygen, making their contribution towards lowering the level of carbon dioxide in the air and, therefore, reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that someone from Dooralong Public School should be the one to raise this because Dooralong Public School was a timber centre in the 1800s. Dooralong had some of the best red cedar in all of Australia but it is all gone now. It is very hard to find any red cedar trees on the New South Wales coast. The Government is trying to say that we need to make sure that we conserve the resource that we have. That means that a Bill such as the one now before the House is very important. The students in the gallery may not be aware that the legislation we are now debating will exempt recycled paper from sales tax. It means that we will be encouraging people and companies to use more recycled paper instead of new paper all the time. I am sure the students would be aware that if we never used recycled paper but only new and fresh paper, it would result in more trees being cut down, more expense and the use of more energy requiring more coal to be burnt in the power stations. It is more energy efficient to recycle paper than to use new paper all the time.

Anyone who followed the debate on Wesley Vale would know that if we used more recycled paper there would be less toxins, such as dioxin, being pumped into Bass Strait and our rivers. While on the question of rivers, the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) has done a lot of research in this area and I understand that by using recycled paper we use less water, which is very important to a dry continent such as Australia. Anything that encourages the use of recycled paper has my full support, and I am sure that the students in the gallery would also encourage Parliament to look at ways to recycle paper. I think we should also do more to recycle some of the plastics and glass that we use. I think that local government could do more to make sure that consumers can return paper, bottles and plastic materials to the manufacturers as easily as possible.

In my electorate there is a firm that uses the tail ends of large paper rolls. I understand that many companies that use paper have massive rolls, but the heads and tails of those rolls of paper are usually thrown away because the companies do not like to interrupt their manufacturing processes at an inconvenient time. A company in my electorate takes those heads and tails and processes them in such a way that they can be used to produce paper products. Every time the company uses one of those heads or tails, it means that new paper does not have to be used. It is just the same as recycling. I suggest to the Government that it should consider extending the sales tax exemption to the products made from the heads and tails of paper rolls. I accept that that is not something I will receive an answer to in next 24 hours, but I hope the Government considers it because I think it is important that we encourage these people as they do their bit to make sure that we do not cut down trees unnecessarily.

The legislation before the House also alters the law which imposes sales tax on computer software, which is an area in which I have been very interested since about 5 May 1988 when a constituent of mine-a Mr Mickey Benefiel, who was then the proprietor of a company called ADP Systems &Software-came to see me in my electorate office at Toukley. Mr Benefiel ran a company which provided a service to people who needed computer work on software which was used in their business. If anyone had a fault with his computer system, he could contact this company and it would come out and investigate the computer programs and implement amendments or corrections and fix up any errors, or perhaps provide extra computer software options so that it could do new things or do things in a better way.

Unfortunately, in the early part of 1988 the Australian Taxation Office wrongly interpreted, in my view, amendments to the sales tax law which this Parliament passed in 1986. Honourable members might be aware that in 1986 we changed the law which imposed sales tax on computer software. We thought that some people were using a licensing system to avoid the regime which then applied to sales tax on computer programs. Unfortunately, I believe the Australian Taxation Office sought to extend the changes that were made in 1986 to cover areas that were never intended to be covered. It was my experience-certainly through Mr Benefiel-that the Tax Office was seeking to impose sales tax on services that were being provided by these computer firms, whereas in the past sales tax applied only to goods such as glasses or pens.

In 1988 the Tax Office-in my view wrongly-said that sales tax was payable on the wages of people who fixed computer programs. That might sound very esoteric, but it resulted in this company being advised by its accountant and Tax Office officials that it was liable for a massive tax bill, plus a penalty, plus interest. I took up this matter with the Tax Office at Newcastle, which is run by Deputy Commissioner Bill Mulheron. I point out that it was not until several months later that we received a reply from Tax Office experts in Canberra. I believe it was as a result of efforts on the part of people such as Mr Benefiel that we were able to convince the Government to change the law on sales tax on computer software. In fact, the letter that finally came from the sales tax section of the Tax Office in Canberra contained the following passage:
. . . the original advice has been reviewed.

That was very nice, because we learnt that the threatened impact on this company was to be waived. However, that threatened action was very disconcerting for everyone involved. I do not wish to criticise Tax officers at Newcastle, because they have done a great job in making sure that those who live between the Hawkesbury River and Port Macquarie receive excellent service. That office has been running some very progressive outreach services to ensure that pensioners and other members of the community can receive good advice from the Tax Office very easily, and I commend it for that.

Before I conclude, I return to what I said earlier about the fact that students in my electorate have been saying that the Government should be doing more about the environment. When I said that I saw a few nods in the gallery from the school students who are visiting Parliament House tonight. I understand that they are from the Aldercourt Primary School. I am sure that all honourable members would join with me in hoping that the students enjoy their brief visit to Parliament House. I am glad that they are seeing Parliament while it is better behaved than was the case between 2 p.m. and 3 p.m. today. That was not our fault but the fault of some other members of Parliament. I am sure that the children in the gallery could teach a few members in this place a thing or two about manners.
Finally, I return to the Opposition's amendment, which in part provides:
. . . the House deplores the Government's economic irresponsibility in increasing sales tax revenue by 200 per cent in an ad hoc and distortionary fashion . . .

I have demonstrated that the single greatest increase in sales tax revenue occurred not under this Government but in 1981-82 when the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer and the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), now the shadow Treasurer, was his main adviser. We know that under its real agenda the Opposition wants to introduce a consumption tax and that is why the amendment includes the words `ad hoc and distortionary fashion'. The Opposition wants to introduce changes to the sales tax laws, changes that are not ad hoc or in a distortionary fashion; in other words, a consumption tax. We know that that is what the Opposition wants, but the Government will do all in its power to ensure that the people of Australia know that that is what the Opposition is up to.

We will make sure that the pensioners out there in the electorate of Adelaide know that the Opposition wants to apply a 10 to 15 per cent consumption tax on cornflakes, the socks they buy and the materials they need for their garden. That will ensure that they can provide more cuts in taxation for their friends in business, such as Mr Elliott. That is how they will be able to provide for the abolition of the capital gains tax on Mr Elliott's shares, so that he can get that $17m in his back pocket. That is what the Opposition is all about-taking money away from the pensioners and the children who spend money in the supermarkets and giving it to Mr Elliott. I am sure that the people of Australia will make the right decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all honourable members are always pleased to see young children in the Parliament, such as the children from Aldercourt Primary School seeing the Parliament in action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for that lecture on policy from the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee). We have been able to learn about the capital gains tax, the consumption tax and cornflakes. He even spoke about the member for Adelaide. I am sure that all those pensioners that he alluded to would be just as grateful for the remarks made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in Port Pirie last week when he referred to the pensioners and veterans of Australia as silly old buggers. If the honourable member wants to match it one for one, I am sure that we can accommodate him.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to support quite a few of the facets that have been raised concerning sales tax and bring to the attention of this House some salient points in regard to sales tax. I was grateful to hear previous speakers refer to recycling. That is the subject on which I shall base my remarks. My speech should last only about 10 minutes, so we can keep future debates going. There is a riddle on tax-free recycled products. It is a growth industry. A lot has been brought to the attention of the public. The honourable member for Dobell spoke about a company that uses the tops and tails and butt reels to sheet. I wonder whether it is the Higgins Trading Company Pty Ltd, whose owner wrote to one of my constituents on 11 August seeking some assurance. The honourable member for Dobell thought that he would not get an answer within 24 hours. It will be much longer than that because the letter to the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Peter Morris) written on 23 August has still not received a reply. The company uses the butts and reels for recycling. It is an operation which converts the printer's waste paper into packaging paper for use in butchers' shops and other food outlets.

The thrust of what the Prime Minister said was correct-it is a matter of utilising existing materials in preference to damaging or depleting scarce and environmentally valuable resources. To encourage this the Prime Minister announced the abolition of the 20 per cent sales tax on recycled paper products. The company went on to say that following discussion between its representatives and senior government policy advisers, sales tax exemption will not apply to its produce despite the obvious recycled use. Since the introduction of sales tax in October 1988 it has noticed a decline in sales due to buyer resistance. The company operates recycling plants in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland and employs over 40 staff in what is a very labour-intensive process. It is very keen to be included in this scheme of events, to outline those facts, to take an interest in this anomaly relating to the exemption of sales tax, and to bring these facts to the attention of those in government. We are still waiting on a reply. That company may be at cross purposes.

A very enterprising woman in my electorate in Adelaide, Mrs Erica Arnold, has developed a recycling aid. Recycling occurs at the kerbside or at the rubbish bin in the kitchen or flat. The housewives of Australia are probably at the coalface of recycling. We have to educate the community. Both sides of the House would agree that we have the opportunity to separate at the source domestic waste to be recycled, whether it is aluminium, plastic or paper. The Scouts and the very many charities have the ability to make money from recycling if they can collect this waste as it finds its way into the kerbsides. It has been said by the Government speakers that, as Government members, they must take the lead in recycling our paper. It was very interested to see a leaked document in which it was impressed upon the Australian Labor Party that it should make available money tins for collection and to have letterheads which are printed on 100 per cent Australian recycled paper. I have a letter here which is written on recycled paper. So it is the intention to lead by example, I presume.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?
—Nothing.
—Commendable.

—It is commendable. I come back to Mrs Arnold and her recycle aid program. As a housewife, she has developed a program where a cross-section fits into a rubbish bin, together with small domestic plastic bags which are used to collect the refuse and place it further into the recycling program. Certainly in South Australia there seems to be some riddle on tax-free recycled products. Mystery surrounds the Federal Government's commitment at an early stage. The sales tax sections of the Australian Taxation Office, in this press release that I referred to, demonstrated which products would be exempt from the tax and when. That brings me to the company that uses butts and tails in its three factories.

SPEECH.PARA: Printing and writing paper, tissue and toilet paper and paper bags made from 100 per cent recycled paper could be tax-free. The community must be alerted to the fact that we do not need virgin white paper. We do not need nappies that are clinically white. We do not need the tissues and toilet paper that are pristine in their colour and appearance. Even though recycling involves several stages, it is less costly in raw materials than new wood. That is an incentive for companies to recycle as much paper fibre as they can. The cellulose fibres that come from the trees and are used for paper making can be reconverted into pulp stock and reformed into paper products. Of the 2.4 million tonnes of paper and paperboard Australia consumes each year, over 900,000 tonnes are recycled-that is, 40 per cent. This is almost the same percentage as in the United Kingdom and West Germany but is approximately 50 per cent higher than in countries such as Sweden and the United States. It is happening in Australia, and community pressure must be brought to bear to continue this concept.

In terms of recycling that is going to be linked to the assistance with sales tax, paper can be recycled in age over time. The cellulose fibres gradually disintegrate so that paper cannot be recycled over and over again. Some paper is obviously irretrievable, such as that from toilet rolls and tissue paper, and paper that has been burnt. Sixty-four per cent of all paper and paper board packaging consumed in Australia is manufactured from recycled material. In order to acquire the many tonnes of waste paper required, paper recycling companies have found it necessary to establish a wide range of collection systems.

I was interested to hear the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) refer to the recycling of freons. I have had the opportunity in this House to refer to a company in Adelaide called Wye Industries Ltd which produces a product called kixotol. The honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott) has also indicated his heavy support for it. This company produces polyurethane, which is blown by CO2, not freon, which just evaporates into the atmosphere. It has fire retardant abilities. It is the polyurethane that goes around the skin and casings of aeroplanes and on the dashboards of cars, and it is very widely used in the softgoods manufacturing industry. It has huge fire retardant abilities when mixed with a paint; so its application is wide ranging. Freon is a dirty word in blowing and in being a propellant. The kixotol-which is really `low toxic' spelt backwards-has something to offer the community and the environment. Its manufacturers would not mind a lazy couple of million dollars from the Government tacked on to the back of the $36m to be given to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, because the company is struggling to survive but has so much to offer. When supporting the recycling of freon gas in motor vehicle air conditioning plants, I bring to the notice of the House the other product from Wye Industries Ltd in Adelaide.

The application of sales tax to the recycling of waste products must be given more than scant regard. It is to be hoped that what is being done tonight will afford an opportunity for greater concessions to be made in this important area of recycling rubbish, whether it be in kerbside bins or municipal destructors. If this principle is applied so that it can enhance our quality of life and improve the environment that Australia requires, the Government and our community will be the leaders and the world can follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill and the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill, and to speak against the amendment moved by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). It is interesting to consider the terms in which it was moved. The shadow Treasurer complains that the Government is increasing sales tax in an ad hoc and distortionary fashion. I went to the Liberal bible, the Economic Action Plan, which is the Liberal and National partys' economic and tax policy. I have to confess that I had a keen desire to look at what they said about sales tax and I wanted to check on the marginal rate. It is interesting that the Opposition can have an Economic Action Plan and an economic and tax policy, yet have not much action and not much policy. Looking for the marginal rate is like looking for the emperor's new clothes. Everybody has to say how marvellous it is but no-one can see it. We are, of course, in that ludicrous situation; nothing is mentioned in the policy about sales tax.

SPEECH.PARA: In his contribution, my colleague the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) suggested that we ought to look at the telling words `ad hoc and distortionary fashion' which appear in the amendment. The amendment is talking about what the Government has been doing. The counter to that-a very deliberate and extortionate one, I would think-is to introduce a consumption tax. The people of Australia have to understand that the Economic Action Plan announced by the Opposition is really the emperor's new clothes. Nobody can see what it is and the only opportunity to find out what it is, heaven forbid, is when the Opposition is in government. One comment by my colleague with which I agree is that the coalition parties will introduce a consumption tax. A consumption tax will hit the weakest section of our community. I visit the five pensioner clubs and senior citizens centres in my electorate of Chifley where we are very proud of our senior citizens. The introduction of a consumption tax will really distress them.

Another point raised was who really increased sales tax the most. The Budget Papers show that it is not this Government and it is not in this year because, under the Labor Government, sales tax has been increased by 5.1 per cent whereas in 1981-82, when you-know-who was in power, sales tax increased by 22 per cent. Which troika was responsible? It was the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is newly restored to the front bench but was then Treasurer in the conservative government, his adviser the honourable member for Wentworth, and the then head of Treasury, none other than Senator Stone.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Jim Carlton was fighting chemists.
—That may be the case. The point is that it is those three who hold the record for increasing sales tax so much.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the removal of sales tax on computer software. Like a number of members, I receive letters from a wide variety of Australian software firms seeking relief in sales tax. I am absolutely delighted to have the privilege tonight of saying to them that I made representations on their behalf but that the Government is very sensitive to the needs of the information industry, which is a growth industry, and that tonight Government members are speaking in support of the changes they sought.

I do not have to remind the House that, in the software industry, it is claimed that Australia has a particular advantage in the skills of its programmers; so it is wonderful that we are not inhibiting them, although, as I understand the Bills, the medians of the programs, that is, the discs or tapes and the packaging, will still be subject to sales tax. The Bill also treats as firmware computer programs on microchips, that is, the programs that are burnt in. So I am delighted to support that proposal.

I also support the lifting of sales tax on recycled paper. This was part of the Prime Minister's comprehensive environmental statement. One of the most encouraging aspects for those concerned with the environment is the growing concern among constituents, and particularly among young school children, about the environment. I am proud to say that my children are better environmentalists than I was at their age, and that is tremendous for the country and it bodes well. I put out a student information kit on the environment and I have had tremendous response from the schools and the students. It is interesting that the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt), an Opposition Liberal member from South Australia, was very complimentary of not only the Government but the Labor Party for seeking to use as much recycled paper as possible. I strongly support that.

The Rooty Hill residents action committee in my electorate, which is an environmental group, mounted a very strong campaign on behalf of the Rooty Hill residents against the mill. It ended up having to raise something like $140,000 to take the matter to court. They are still working very hard at fund-raising and are to be congratulated for the job they have done. They approached me concerning the shredded paper coming out of my office. They asked me whether I would be prepared to assist them by giving the shredded paper to them. I am pleased to say that I was only too happy to do that for a time but, unfortunately, the price being paid by merchants for shredded paper does not make the exercise worthwhile. I hope that that situation will change and that there will be opportunities for people to put shredded paper from our electorate offices into the system so that it can be recycled and not burnt off and thrown onto dumps.

I would like the initiative announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the proposals embodied in these Bills to be picked up by all State local authorities. There is still a lot that councils can do to assist recycling, in particular to split the refuse from households into paper, glass, cans and other refuse. We need to work cooperatively and embark upon a public education program. I urge my two local government councils, Penrith and Blacktown, to pick up this challenge.

There is a great opportunity for States to put deposits on glass bottles and cans. I commend what is being done in the recycling of aluminium cans but I believe we ought to go much further. It is a pity that the initiative taken many years ago in the State of Oregon has not been copied elsewhere. It introduced a deposit system which completely cured a severe litter problem there but, more importantly, it worked very constructively in creating concern and caring for the environment.

Lastly, there is one element of what the New South Wales Government is doing in terms of recycling to which I object; this may appear a bit inconsistent. As honourable members will know, there have always been proposals to turn the tidal waters inland and to harness the great river systems on the east coast of Australia. But I am afraid to say that the New South Wales Government has come up with a far more imaginative program to turn inwards the sewerage lines of Sydney, from the north shore and eastern suburbs and to inundate the western suburbs. I hope you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will forgive me for being parochial in raising this, but I am sure you can understand that we in the western suburbs object very mightily to receiving this pollution that we have not generated and that we are not in any way involved in.

In conclusion, I reiterate the point that I made earlier, that the most heartening thing is that young school children are becoming more environmentally conscious. I am sure, for example, that the school children from the Frankston Special School in Bob Chynoweth's electorate of Dunkley, who are in the House today, feel the same as the school children in my electorate. I have received a number of letters from young primary school children asking what they as concerned young Australians can do about the environment. There is a lot they can do, and I am sure they are pleased that this Government is tackling that problem. I commend the Bills to the House.
