TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable members who have participated in this cognate debate on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill 1989 and the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill 1989. There are a few remarks I wish to make in relation to those contributions. In doing so, I emphasise the significant concession the Government has made in the two computer program Bills by removing the sales tax on computer software. This has come about as a consequence of the need to ensure that the sales tax law is clear in its application and that the avenue for its avoidance is closed off in this area. It is perhaps not surprising, therefore, that as far as I am aware the changes have been welcomed by those engaged in the software industry in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure honourable members will also appreciate the other main measure in the Sales Tax Laws (Computer Programs) Amendment Bill. I refer to the ongoing statutory guarantee that sales tax payers will be allowed up to 27 days after royal assent is given to this and subsequent legislation imposing sales tax obligations from an earlier date to find out about and meet those obligations without attracting penalties. This guarantee will give peace of mind to those taxpayers affected by such sales tax changes and who are unsure of what, if anything, they should be doing prior to the changes becoming law some time later.

The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill (No. 2) gives effect to four measures, three of which are Budget initiatives while the fourth was announced in the environment statement from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in July this year. I am sure honourable members appreciate that the measures contained in the Bill will reduce both the amount of sales tax required to be paid by the Australian community and the administrative obligations taxpayers must meet under the sales tax law. The measure announced in the Prime Minister's environment statement, to exempt from sales tax certain paper products where the paper in those products is made wholly from recycled paper, represents a constructive incentive by the Government to encourage the manufacture and use of recycled paper. It is a limited exemption. While the Government is exploring the possibility of expanding the range of recycled paper products that are to be exempt from sales tax, we recognise the difficulties associated with this kind of exemption, such as introducing tax avoidance opportunities and economic distortions.

We on this side of the House want to implement as a matter of priority a constructive environmental policy. To do so it is necessary to consider carefully all the relevant information. The Budget measures contained in the Bill also include significant assistance for small manufacturers, subcontractors carrying out activities of a manufacturing nature and producers of flavoured milk. Touching briefly on each of these measures, sales of goods by small manufacturers with average annual sales of $50,000 or less, or an annual sales tax liability that does not exceed $1,000, will be tax free. The range of goods exempt from sales tax when they are for use by a subcontractor exclusively in carrying out activities of a manufacturing nature is to be extended. This amendment will be of great benefit to certain subcontractors who perform work on behalf of other businesses where the business is entitled to sales tax exemption but the subcontractor is not. Manufacturers and wholesalers of flavoured milk drinks will benefit from the reduction in the milk content requirement that drinks have to meet to be eligible for the concessional rate of tax.

Before I conclude my remarks on the two Bills removing sales tax on computer software, I cannot let go uncorrected the suggestions made by the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) that the earlier sales tax Bills on software introduced in November last year were withdrawn because they did not accord with the software industry's understanding of the Budget announcement of the changes to be made and that those Bills did not reflect the Government's intention. If those Bills had not given effect to the Government's intentions at the time, namely, to remove sales tax on customised software and to impose sales tax on packaged software transferred electronically, those Bills would not have been introduced.

The industry outcry that arose after the introduction of the Bills related primarily to the qualification to the removal of sales tax on customised software. The qualification was that the tax would remain payable on packaged software used in creating that customised software. Apparently, the industry had expected that only some types of such packaged software would be taxed. However, the Budget announcement gave no indication that this would be so. Nevertheless, given the software industry's concerns that the Bills were not satisfactory, the Government had further extensive discussions with industry representatives to explore those concerns. Following these discussions the Government concluded that the Bills would not adequately address fundamental problems associated with applying sales tax to computer software and that instead sales tax on all computer software other than firmware should be removed, as the two computer program Bills being considered propose to do. It was that conclusion that necessitated the withdrawal of last November's Bills. I reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Wentworth and I commend the Bills to the House.

The change to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill relates to the measure announced in the 1989-90 Budget to extend the range of goods to be exempt from sales tax where those goods are for use by a subcontractor exclusively in carrying out activities on behalf of one or more manufacturers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1989 primarily amends the Wool Marketing Act and then makes some corrections to and tidies up quite a number of other pieces of rural industry legislation. The main purpose of the amendments to the Wool Marketing Act is to establish a Wool Research and Development Council which comes at a time of significant activity in the wool industry. Significant purchases of wool are being made by the Wool Marketing Authority to maintain the floor price. The Australian Wool Council is about to meet for its annual review and to take account of the work of the International Wool Secretariat (IWS) in relation to wool promotion. Recently the Government announced that in two years time it will be terminating any contribution to wool promotion although it has now made an announcement that it will be helping Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd with some exports, which once again reveals this Government's double standard concerning industry. We have a crisis in our live sheep trade to Saudi Arabia and we have a potential oversupply of mutton. The Bill itself is a compromise after lengthy debate between the industry on the one hand and the Government on the other as to whether there should be a research and development council or a corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: With the wool stockpile a combination of circumstances has caused wool purchased by the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) since 1 July to increase from under 200,000 bales to over one million bales. There are a number of reasons for this. First, there is a 20 per cent increase in offerings this year compared with last year. That is made up of an 8 1/2 per cent production increase, plus some carryover for sales from the previous season, and the previous season itself was a record year of production. This increased offering exacerbates the concentration that always occurs whereby most wool is sold in the first half of the wool selling season; that is, about 60 per cent of the total offering for the year. Traditionally, the Australian Wool Corporation will buy in during that period, if it is to buy in, because of that concentration of selling and the fact that it coincides with a period of slack demand in the Northern Hemisphere, caused by holidays, et cetera. Generally, the Wool Corporation has been a net seller rather than buyer of wool in the second half of the wool selling season-that is, in the new year.

The final reason is the withdrawal of China from the market. China had moved up to be the second largest buyer of Australian wool. Not only is China no longer in the market but also there is the indirect consequence that other countries, including Japan, which has reduced its purchases, used to buy and then on-sell our wool to China. So the stockpile, which has rapidly built up to over one million bales, could easily grow to two million bales by the end of the wool selling season. The woolgrowers' market support fund has $1.8 billion to purchase that wool. Beyond that, the Corporation has the ability to borrow commercially and, therefore, in theory, the stockpile could grow to well over two million bales.

I want to indicate my complete confidence in that marketing policy of the Australian Wool Corporation and its maintenance of the present floor price. The present situation is not new. A stockpile of over one million bales has existed for more than half of the years that there has been a floor or reserve price arrangement. The Wool Corporation has always resold that wool at a profit and, in so doing, has added billions of dollars to the exports of this country. This highlights the importance of the wool industry in terms of exports. The industry is our most consistent and significant net export industry, with exports of $6 billion last year. That money stays in Australia and that should be the real test of the export value of an industry. But, because of the wool that has been purchased and put into the stockpile, exports could be down $2 billion this year to about $4 billion.

I remind everyone that the policy of the AWC over the years has been sound in that the wool has been ultimately sold at a profit to the benefit of all Australians. One must bear in mind that there will be a $2 billion reduction, or potential reduction, for wool, and reductions of at least $2 billion to $3 billion for tourism, $500m for wheat and $500m for meat and sheep.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all down.

—As my colleague said, they will all be down. This country's trade deficit for this 12 months period will not be the $18 1/2 billion as guesstimated by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the Budget. It will be possibly $25 billion and this will have very serious ramifications for interest rates and the standard of living of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: Government support for this very important and great industry which has $4 billion to $6 billion worth of exports is, first of all, $16m a year for research on a dollar for dollar basis. That is the standard rural industry research arrangement. Nobody disagrees with that and I think it has strong bipartisan support. The Government also gives $25m for the overseas promotion of wool. The wool industry has always had a great record of concentrating on research. The industry and all Australians have benefited from that investment. In fact, wool has the highest percentage of industry contribution in terms of research work done by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). Once again, one can point to a double standard in that the rural industries are putting in a far higher percentage of the total research cost of work done by CSIRO than are other sections of industry. Woolgrowers this year will invest $434m for their future; $230m for the market support fund-the revolving fund; and $190m for wool promotion through the International Wool Secretariat. The IWS will contribute $16m.

I come back to the decision that was announced yesterday in relation to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd. Kodak has annual exports of about $200m to $250m. The Government will be providing that company $13m a year for three years. Yet, although the wool industry has exports of $4 billion to $6 billion a year, the Government has announced that in two years time it will be terminating any direct assistance-that is, the $25m for wool promotion-and will continue the standard dollar for dollar industry research arrangement which, as I said earlier, indicates the higher commitment of rural industries to research compared with that of industry generally. I want to highlight that double standard. This great industry of Australia, which has its problems from time to time, puts more of its money into research than do other industries. We do not have any idea what Kodak will be putting in for research. Yet, the Government has said that in two years time the $25m for wool promotion, which will be all spent overseas because the wool growers themselves spend $16m each year for promotion in Australia, will be terminated. The wool industry deserves better than that.

But this highlights the lack of equity on the part of this Government in supporting the industries of Australia-whether it is Kodak, the banks, the airlines or the waterfront. It is interesting to note that today the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority presented a report on the manning and the operation of bulk grain terminals in Australia. Honourable members will recall that some months ago the industry itself wanted to proceed with enterprise employment-in other words, the exporter determining the amount of labour and what type of labour would be employed in the bulk terminals, particularly at Fisherman Island and Port Kembla. But due to tremendous pressure from the Government, the Wheat Board backed down and agreed that the Reform Authority should take control.

The Reform Authority has indicated that there will be no enterprise employment on these two bulk grain terminals and, presumably from that, on any other bulk terminals in Australia or on the waterfront generally. We will have a union dominated and managed industry in which the union will say how many people will be employed. So much for the Government putting pressure on the waterfront and achieving micro-economic reform to reduce the exorbitant costs that export industries have to face. They are required to be more than efficient in world terms in order to meet competition from other countries, notwithstanding the fact that our interest rates and inflation rates are twice those of our competitors.

Other aspects of the sheep industry are very important and critical at present. We have a large number of ageing sheep because, with better wool prices, many sheep have been kept for an extra year. We now have a situation in which we need significant mutton sales. It is preferable that these sheep be slaughtered rather than shot. The price of the sheep has fallen considerably. Live sheep sales are important in order to maintain a commercial price for sheep of a certain age and type. With the termination, hopefully just for the time being, of the Saudi Arabian market, the price of sheep of this type has fallen by up to 50 per cent.

We have had more interesting news today on that front. Hopefully, it is good news. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has agreed to write to King Fahd of Saudi Arabia indicating the importance of this trade to Australia which is about $130m to $150m a year. This part of the industry is certainly not getting any support from the Government such as is being given to Kodak. I raised this matter in Parliament on 31 August and suggested that we need a higher level of intervention on a diplomatic basis to indicate to the Saudis that this is a very serious matter for Australia in terms of both trade and more general relations. We have enjoyed very good relations with that kingdom. The Prime Minister said that I was stupid. He said:
The honourable member should just wait for a minute for once in his life instead of being stupid.
He said that Opposition members were being stupid. Here we are, two months later--

TALK.START.PARA: —Wasted all this time.
—We have wasted all this time, there is a crisis in the industry, the price of sheep has plummeted dramatically and now the Prime Minister is doing the right thing.
—Now who is being shorn?
—That is right. Those exporters have been absolutely fleeced. It is a very sad tale, is it not?
—Do you think you are ready for office?

—I think that our cracks are as good as the Government's. However, even if he has done so much later than he should have, I commend the Prime Minister for now accepting his responsibility. I also commend him on an earlier intervention with the Canadian Prime Minister, which I have used as an example of what can be achieved for the canned fruit trade between our countries. The problem of the Canada-United States free trade agreement puts at risk our best export market for canned fruit, worth $35m. The proposal that the Prime Minister brought back from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, after talking to Prime Minister Mulroney, is not a certainty. Negotiations are necessary both on the tariff for US fruit and Australian fruit and on any trade-offs that may be necessary. Nevertheless, the Prime Minister's intervention was a positive one. When somebody does that I commend him for it. I just wish that with the live sheep trade he had intervened two months earlier when I believe-and I hope that it will now-that it would have had a positive result.

SPEECH.PARA: The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) seeks to establish the Wool Research and Development Council, which is a compromise between the competing views of the industry on the one hand, which wanted something like the existing arrangement to continue, and, on the other, the research and development corporation model which we will be debating in general terms later this week, of which the meat industry is the best example and which many in primary industry believe is an improvement over the council model.

However, the wool industry is different. It is a more integrated industry between the grower and the statutory authority-the Australian Wool Corporation. It has an international presence through the International Wool Secretariat. It is, as an industry, more attuned to research and development. The Wool Council already has in place research subcommittees. Wool has an established accountability arrangement. Whether one is talking about accountability for research and development or for marketing in general, through the statutory authority-the Corporation-I believe that the wool industry has the best accountability arrangement of any of the rural industries. In addition to presenting its annual report to Parliament, the Wool Council-the peak industry body-has twice yearly meetings in different parts of Australia. As I said earlier, the next one will be in Perth in the very near future.

Research and development is very important to the wool industry. The level of research is increasing by 5 per cent per annum and, for textile research within that total framework, by 10 per cent per annum-that is, it has the major priority for wool research. Production research-that is, to improve on-farm production-has a lower priority. It has a real increase each year but nowhere near to the same extent. There is not much point producing a product if it cannot be sold profitably. The more value that can be added to a product, which does not necessarily mean by further processing but by selling that product in the luxury section of the market, the better. Obviously, any research that can be done to push wool into that end of the market is very valuable.

Australia has a significant role in textile research. Whereas the great majority of the development work through the IWS is spent overseas, we must remember that 70 per cent of the IWS's budget is from Australian wool-growers. No other industry in this country has that commitment to international promotion of an Australian product-to expertise and development of that product. The money is spent, through the IWS, in the major markets-the fashion areas of northern Europe, et cetera-which determine the use of different types of competing fibres.

I am advised that the present level of the levy is 0.35 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) and, under the Government's arrangement, up to 0.5 per cent of GDP is eligible for a dollar for dollar contribution. Wool research funds have definitely been improved by the price increase of the last few years, but one has to remember that it has fallen by 30 per cent over the last 18 months. I have no doubt, in view of the wool industry's proud record, that as more money is needed for wool research that percentage levy will be increased as necessary to the maximum. The coalition Opposition supports the legislation.

Many parts of my electorate have suffered severe dry spells and drought over the past few seasons. Parts of the area suffer salinity and land degradation. Several land care groups have been established to deal with the problem. One of the most impressive I have seen is the Mundubbera land care group called the Central Burnett Land Management Group. It has established an extensive project to deal with several aspects of conservation. Last year, the group received a grant of $73,000 to assist with the scheme. Parts of the Mundubbera area suffer the basic symptoms of soil degradation: that of soil erosion, soil salination and some effects of vegetation degradation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government is assisting land care in conjunction with other levels of government. Land care will consist of three elements. The 1990s will be declared the Decade of Land Care. There will be a review of all policies and an expansion of the national soil conservation program. During the Decade of Land Care, the Government will provide over $320m for land care and related tree planting and remnant vegetation conservation programs. In 1989-90, $23.4m will be provided to the national soil conservation program. Ten million dollars will be used to overcome problems associated with insufficient data on land capability and the location and extent of degradation. About $6m will be used to fund projects of land care groups, coordinators and the preparation of farm and regional plans. About $5m has been allocated to research and development projects including research into economic issues. The remaining funds will be directed at information and technology transfer projects, such as school curriculum material, ecological advice for landholders, technical bulletins and training programs.

The national soil conservation program has grown appreciably since 1983-84. Over the past five years, the program has contributed to over 400 projects. There are about 200 land care groups throughout Australia and a further 1,000 groups are intended by the year 2000. The program is of concern to my electorate. A land degradation severity index shows that both the coast and parts of the Central Burnett and Isis areas have a moderate problem which is the second worst scenario on the index. There are tables suggesting the interrelationship between tree clearing and land degradation problems.

The case appears to have been proven in my electorate. Most of my electorate has shown a severe-70 to 100 per cent-clearing of trees since settlement began. That was only 200 years ago. Three-quarters of our rainforest is gone. Large areas of what was once rainforest, cleared for agriculture in the 1800s and early 1900s, are now unproductive, infested with weeds, heavily eroded and swept by fire. The poplar box woodlands area of central Queensland is an area under threat. There is now the potential to clear 30 to 50 per cent of the 100 million hectares of poplar box woodland in Queensland through the aerial application of a chemical called graslan. The operation would cost between $2 billion and $4 billion. My complaint with the Queensland Government is that the chemical is freely available at produce agencies and there are no supervised guidelines for its use. To prove the point, I sent a staff member to buy it. She had no difficulty obtaining it and was not questioned about its intended use.

Given the fragile nature of parts of our environment, I would have hoped that a closer monitoring of chemicals such as graslan could be undertaken. The clearing in questions if it went ahead, would mean the loss of some five billion trees. The region represents the heartland of Australia's remaining koala population. Scientists have argued that the area would be vulnerable to salination and overgrazing. Last night the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) mentioned that I have raised this matter before, and that is correct. I am concerned about our environment, particularly in Queensland. It is not so much the chemical but the action of the Queensland Government that worries me. The former Minister for Primary Industries, Neville Harper, said graslan was merely another tool to clear the land. Any chemical with the capabilities of graslan needs to be monitored carefully. That comment from Mr Harper reminds me of a comment from another fool, Barry Goldwater, who once said that the atom bomb was merely another weapon. Mr Harper is now Minister for Land Management. That is like putting Nero in charge of the fire brigade. The Queensland Nationals cannot control law and order, they cannot control drought relief, and I do not believe they can control the use of chemicals. The problem we have had with dieldrin is another classic example.

Australia currently imports about $1.5 billion worth of timber and pulp and paper products, accounting for 10 per cent of the current account deficit. (Quorum formed) As the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker), who called the quorum, has complimented me on my concern for the environment, I will repeat what I said. I am concerned for the environment. It is not so much the use of the chemical graslan but the behaviour of the Queensland Government that worries me. The former Minister for Primary Industries, Neville Harper, said graslan was merely another tool to clear land. Any chemical with the capabilities of graslan needs to be monitored carefully. That comment from Mr Harper reminds me of a comment from another fool, Barry Goldwater, who once said that the atom bomb was merely another weapon. Mr Harper is now Minister for Land Management. That is like putting Nero in charge of the local fire brigade. The National Party cannot control law and order-I am pleased the honourable member for Wannon agrees with me-it cannot control drought relief and it cannot control the use of chemicals. The problems we have had in the past with dieldrin highlight that fact. I will now get back to where I was when the quorum was called.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The honourable member is misrepresenting me. I did not say any such thing.
—There is no point of order.

—I understand that the Liberals are a bit touchy; they do have to live with the National Party. Australia has about one million hectares of plantations-about 2.2 per cent of the total area of forest. Most of the plantations are softwood and 50,000 hectares are hardwood. There are examples throughout Australia of trees being grown primarily for environmental reasons but the value of the timber helps offset the cost. I have read that in Canberra pine forests were initially grown to restore and improve degraded land and protect the quality of Canberra's water supply. As well as being a popular recreation area, the forests now pay for themselves and return a small profit from logging. Formerly unproductive land has been converted to sustainable productive use, providing employment for 450 people.

SPEECH.PARA: Research has improved the economics of hardwood plantations. Plantations in the future are expected to achieve double the yield of unmanaged native forests on the same site. A significant commercial development can be derived from specialty or feature timber or multipurpose woodlots on plantations. In the past, Australia had ample quantities of blackwood, scheer ash, rosewood, Queensland maple, silky oak, mountain ash and cypress pine. Today, Australia imports feature timbers. A decision to grow feature timbers is a 50-year investment, but one well worth making. There is every reason, however, to suggest that the decision to grow such trees can also be a useful environmental tool.

As the Government has recognised, we cannot afford any longer to blindly ignore the environmental difficulties on our farming land. Wheat yield per hectare on the Darling Downs is five times the national average. Each year it loses four to eight millimetres, or eight million tonnes, of rich black topsoil. At this rate the soil will be gone in 30 to 50 years. In a 1985 publication entitled State of the Environment in Australia, it was estimated that the value of nutrients in soil washed from the Darling Downs in drought-breaking rains in 1983 was about $2 billion.

It is in farmers' interests and Australia's interests that farmers become greenies on issues of soil conservation and land degradation. Agriculture still plays the foremost role in our export capacity. So it is in the economic self-interest of all rural communities to get behind the land care schemes already in place. Over 2.6 million square kilometres of our land have been assessed as needing treatment for degradation and in 1983 two-thirds of Australia's farmland needed soil conservation treatment. That is a sad indictment. It is a major challenge, and I believe we can overcome it. I commend the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and the local communities for the roles they are playing in facing up to the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) covers a wide range of rural issues, as the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) have already alluded to. Frankly, the debate tonight has reflected a wide range of rural issues, as I am sure you would be the first to acknowledge, Mr Deputy Speaker. Many rural industries are covered by this legislation, and among the Acts affected by this omnibus Bill are the Wool Marketing Act, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act, the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation Act, the Honey Levy Collection Act, the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act, the Barley Research Levy Collection Act, the Oilseeds Levy Act, the Rural Industries Research Act and the Wheat Marketing Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be relieved to know, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, will be relieved to know, and I suspect the House will be relieved to know, that it is not my intention tonight at this late hour to address all the aspects of the Bill. In fact, I am somewhat exasperated by the fact that the limited number of sitting days that the Parliament has had will force us to prune our opportunity to debate the legislation currently before the House.

I want to pick up some of the comments that were made earlier in the debate by the honourable member for Murray about wool marketing. I have to concede as one who represents the electorate of Wakefield-the electorate of Wakefield includes the merino capital of the world, the town of Burra-not only that the wool industry plays a major role in the capacity of Australia to earn export dollars, but also the research for the wool industry is funded by woolgrowers at levels that make other initiatives in other industries seem almost paltry by comparison. Because of the huge research effort that has characterised the wool industry and, as the honourable member for Murray said, because of the level of promotion that growers have themselves committed to it, as I understand it, the wool industry has made approaches to the agriculture Minister and successfully sought from him a concession to have set up a research and development council rather than a research and development corporation. The Minister has wisely acceded to this request from the industry and the Opposition supports the Minister in this particular move. We recognise that research in wool is essential, that the wool industry is unique and that a research council may well more appropriately meet both its historic and future needs than a corporation would.

While I am on my feet I indicate that both the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker)-he is not in the chamber now-and the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) had sought to participate in this debate because of the lifelong interest they have had in the wool industry and the contribution they have made to it, but the shortage of available time for debate tonight will not make that possible.
The honourable member for Murray has already made much of the real input that growers make in wool research and wool promotion. He said, and I quote him:
. . . last year growers paid $434 million in levies for promotion and market support-$25 million up on the previous year.
That is an astonishing amount of money. He continued:
From these levies $230 million went into the market support fund, $190 million to promotion and $14 million to research.

The woolgrowers of Australia have already made a realistic commitment to addressing this nation's balance of payments deficit. They have put their money where their mouths are in an effort to improve both research into wool and the promotion that wool enjoys on a world market. Sadly, in spite of their efforts and through no fault of their own, the capacity that wool has to be a major export earner in this country will not be reflected in the figures. It is expected that wool earnings could go from somewhere near $6 billion in the last financial year to a figure closer to $3 billion in this financial year. Be that as it may, the point remains that the growers have contributed 70 per cent of the promotion budget of the International Wool Secretariat, and they have shown a real commitment to the wool industry. The Opposition is prepared to support the legislation before the House because the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, recognising the commitment of both the wool industry and the woolgrowers to addressing Australia's need for export income, feels that research in wool would be better addressed by a wool council than a wool corporation.

I want to address another aspect of the Bill, pick up the comments made earlier by the honourable member for Hinkler, and reflect for a moment on the impact of the soil conservation amendments currently before the House. As a representative of a rural electorate, I am somewhat distressed at the direction the debate on soil conservation is taking. Along with every other member of the House I applaud the heightened consciousness in Australia of the importance of soil. Everyone recognises that the key to Australia's agricultural productivity, in many cases the key to our capacity to improve our export earnings, and certainly the key to feeding Australia and enabling us to make a contribution to feeding the world, is the way in which we treat our soil. I am distressed about the impression that is abroad in the community that soil conservation is an issue that is largely being neglected by farmers and that the new-found enthusiasm for soil conservation measures has largely resulted from urban initiatives. This bothers me. I want to address the fundamental issue; that is, that even the Government's land care program, successfully launched last week and representing cooperation between the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation, has not been successful in removing the impression abroad that land and soil conservation has largely been an urban initiative.

About five weeks ago I visited Roseworthy College. I accompanied the principal of the college, Dr Thistlethwaite, around that key agricultural learning institution. Dr Thistlethwaite showed me some of the photos that had been put together as part of the college's history. The astonishing thing about those photos, taken over 100 years ago and reflecting what has happened in college growth over that time, was that, wherever there was a photograph of agricultural activity, the photograph was set to a backdrop that was denuded of trees. These photographs were very largely taken in the mid-north of South Australia, in some of South Australia's most productive country. The early settlers had taken what they thought was a very responsible decision in removing trees in order to increase productivity-and in the short term, of course, they were absolutely right. The removal of trees is not a recent phenomenon. Our early settlers quickly recognised that their soil, farming and tillage practices were encouraging soil erosion. So in South Australia we had not an urban initiative but a rural initiative to establish soil conservation boards. These soil conservation boards recognised that not only in the mid-north, but also in the Mallee areas of South Australia, in the fragile soils frequently exposed to drought, sandhills were growing larger and soil was moving. The work of these soil conservation boards found that, for example, the sowing of rye on sandhills allowed the sandhills to be held and crops to be re-established in the area. Predecessors of mine such as the Hon. Bert Kelly, a former member for Wakefield-he had his own farm in the Tarlee area of South Australia-established some of the early contour banking techniques that prevented the soil erosion problem from expanding.

I want to applaud what has been done by farmers in my State and around Australia to conserve Australia's precious agricultural topsoil. I am not critical of the land care program, though I suspect that we need to do much more than is being done, and I am not critical of the new-found enthusiasm that the electorate at large is showing for the environment and for care of the soil. I am critical of the fact that there has been very little recognition of the role played by farmers throughout my generation and previous generations to correct the difficulties being experienced on the land. I have to restate the case that frequently it has been the astute use of modern chemicals and modern techniques that have been developed by research and the astute adoption of recommendations from soil conservation boards around South Australia and across the nation that have enabled us to put in place soil conservation measures. This is not a recent phenomenon; it has gone on for some decades.

The legislation currently before the House, which amends the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act's current provision for a committee with a maximum membership of seven, by lifting that level to 12, is something that the Opposition supports because it allows a greater input into the question of how we go about soil conservation. But we need to acknowledge that, before the Federal Government took a role in soil conservation and the establishment of land care programs, local communities, through their soil conservation boards, were already endeavouring to address many of the shortcomings. The difficulty they faced was, simply, inadequate funding.

The Opposition acknowledges that in this year's Budget the Government has increased funding for the national soil conservation program by more than 100 per cent, to $23.4m. That is applauded. The Government has said that it intends to provide a total of $260m to the program over the next 10 years. That is also applauded. But alongside what has just been made available to the Kodak company, suddenly soil conservation no longer seems to be the priority that it was presumed to be when the Prime Minister announced the Year of Land Care. What we are to spend on soil conservation in one year will not be as much as the money that has been offered to the Kodak company. I call on the Government to recognise the demand there is around Australia for sensitive soil conservation measures. The community is already prepared to make those conservation measures work but needs more realistic funding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I will respond to the comments of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) about the land care program. I am pleased that the Opposition supports the Government's activities in this area. It is certainly an area that has been neglected by past governments. This Government, clearly, has recognised the need to fund land care. Certainly the Minister at the table, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), has been one of the forerunners in this area. I had the opportunity some time ago to visit the town of Inglewood in the area of the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), who I see is here, to represent the Minister. I watched at first hand the activities of the local farming community who have participated in a very successful land care program. Certainly the honourable member is correct in saying that farmers have been aware of the problem for many years but have not had the support from government which they are getting from this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) covered a number of issues which I am pleased to associate myself with. He shares my concern about the problems the people in Queensland have had with the National Party Government in that State. Hopefully, that will soon be rectified and Queensland will get back to some sort of order.

I am very pleased to be able to take the opportunity to participate in this debate on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) tonight. The changes that this Bill will bring into effect show this Government's determination to get moving industries that those opposite ran into the ground when they were in government. Part of this Bill will allow Wool Research and Development Fund moneys to be used for commercial exploitation of the results of research. Overall responsibility for planning, funding and coordinating research and development lies with the Wool Research and Development Council (WRDC). The Council's objective is to plan and recommend a research and development program with the principal aims of increasing demand through new products and processes and by more efficient production and marketing of wool textiles and increasing the efficiency of sustainable raw wool production.

The WRDC has an expenditure program of $56m for 1989-90, which is the largest fund established under the Government's rural industry research policy. It envisages growth in research and development expenditure over the next five years of a nominal 15 per cent per annum, with expenditure forecast to rise to $82.2m by 1993-94. The latest forecasts by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics have indicated that Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) stocks would close at 900,000 bales at the end of 1989-90. This would represent an increase of 712,000 bales over the closing stocks as at 30 June 1989. The market indicator was forecast to average 905 cubic kilograms in 1989-90, a fall of 7.6 per cent over the average for 1988-89. Despite the increased volume of wool exports, the fall in wool prices assumed in the Bureau's September forecast would mean that the value of wool exports would fall from $5,960m in 1989 to $4,910m in 1989-90 as a result of a shortage and uncertainty of foreign exchange in China and, to a lesser extent, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, two of Australia's major customers.

The current state of the wool market needs to be viewed against the longer term trend and movements. A significant expansion in production of wool in Australia has occurred. Production is now predicted to reach 1,027 kilotonnes in 1989-90, the largest clip on record and up by over 48 per cent since this Government came to office.

The amendment to the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 is in line with the national soil conservation program (NSCP) which has expanded rapidly. The budget has increased from $6m in 1987-88 to $23.4m in 1989-90. Similar levels of funding have been promised by this Government over the next 10 years. Financial assistance is now provided under four subprograms: community land care support, research, major program support, and public awareness, education and training. The number of NSCP project applications received has risen from around 100 in early years to 500 in 1989-90. The Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 currently provides for a soil conservation advisory committee with a maximum membership of seven, to make recommendations to the Minister with respect to priorities and strategies for activities by the Commonwealth relating to soil conservation and for matters relevant to the operation of the Act such as project selection.

On 26 October the Minister for Resources, Senator Peter Cook, announced the formation of a private company to manage a national information and education campaign in support of 1990, the Year of Land Care and the beginning of the Decade of Land Care. The land care initiatives have been welcomed by the rural community as a very positive step forward. These moves have been well received within the rural areas of my own electorate of Oxley and there are moves under way to establish land care groups.

One of the changes these amendments will bring is to increase the number of persons with experience and special knowledge of, or educational qualifications relevant to, soil conservation on the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee from not less than four to not less than five. This will bring the total number of the Committee to eight. The maximum number of members with these qualifications who can be appointed to the Committee has not yet been prescribed, to enable flexibility in appointing members without the need for further changes in the legislation.

I now turn to the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Research and Development Act 1985. These amendments will alter the Act to clarify the intention of allowing the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation to invest surplus money in specified ways without needing to seek the permission of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy for each transaction. At the close of the financial year 1988-89, the Meat and Live-stock Corporation's financial position was much better than at the end of June 1988. This year's operating situation shows a surplus of $15m. Some $12m of this year's surplus will be used to rebuild the Corporation's reserves. The turnaround in the financial position compared with the year ending 1988 can be attributed to an increase in income and reduction in the rate of organochlorin testing. Income flowing from higher levies which were operative for the full year resulted in a 58 per cent increase to $85m. Despite the increase, budgeted income for the period was adversely affected by a decline in sheep, lamb and cattle slaughtering. During the year, overall expenditure increased by 8 per cent.

The very good outlook for export markets has encouraged herd and flock rebuilding. In 1988-89, Australia exported 723,726 tonnes of meat. Exports to Japan and Korea grew strongly. The United States remains Aus- tralia's largest export market. (Quorum formed) I did not realise that I was saying anything that would upset the Opposition. I would have thought that honourable members opposite would have been quite prepared to support this legislation. However, I am pleased to see that all my colleagues are now in the chamber to support me. Obviously in the rural areas of Australia the farming community has a lot of concerns, and that is why this side of the House is the most strongly represented party in the rural sector of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly on the Queensland scene.

—Yes, on the Queensland scene, come 2 December, there will be no-one left from the National Party of Australia. A moment ago I was providing a few statistics on the export of beef cattle and I made the point that the good outlook for export markets has encouraged herd and flock rebuilding. In 1988-89, Australia exported 723,726 tonnes of meat. Exports to Japan and Korea grew strongly. The United States remains Australia's largest export market. Shipments of beef, veal and mutton were restricted in late 1988 due to provisions in the United States meat import law. In August 1988 the United States asked Australia to `voluntarily' restrain beef, veal and mutton exports to the United States to 363,000 tonnes. SPEECH.PARA: The Technical Developments Division of the Corporation ran four major projects in 1988-89. The producer feedback project aims to encourage over-the-hooks trading and the use of price grids which reflect market requirements. Following extensive research of consumers, home economists and retailers, the division developed a retail labelling system based on uses of various cuts. The system called `right meat' aims to increase consumer satisfaction with beef.

The Authority for Uniform Specification Meat and Livestock-AUS-MEAT-started abattoir operations on 1 July 1987. Its initial charter was to implement a uniform language based on an objective measurement to describe meat and livestock. This was to be the cornerstone to establishing a system throughout the meat industry, with benefits to producers and buyers, both locally and overseas, of Australian meat. Firstly, it would allow buyers to describe their requirements using the language. Secondly, market needs could be passed on to the producers in terms everyone could understand, allowing producers to target markets through breeding or management. The AUS-MEAT system is based on accreditation of abattoirs and boning rooms which adopt certain standards of operations. AUS-MEAT area managers make unannounced visits to accredited establishments every 10 to 15 days to monitor the operations of the AUS-MEAT system. Establishments not satisfactorily maintaining their quality assurance program or misusing the language have it pointed out to their management.

The amendments remove inconsistencies in the Act that resulted from amendments made in 1987. The effects of these amendments will be to provide greater flexibility to the operations of the Australian Meat and Livestock Research Development Corporation to recruit senior staff who are more suitable to carry out the duties of furthering the programs I have previously outlined. This Government has been one of the greatest reforming governments that this country has ever had. No matter how much those opposite carry on, those are the facts. These amendments will allow the various authorities named in this Bill to operate with greater efficiency and responsibility. I do not wish to take any further time. I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure tonight to join the debate and support the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). There is a long shaft of amendments: the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has taken the opportunity to introduce seven or eight amendments to various Acts. Of course, the legislation covers the whole spectrum of rural industry in Australia, which gives us a great opportunity to talk on almost anything, and I hope you note that, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Bill allows me, as the member for Maranoa, to talk on almost anything in respect of primary industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the House that the first amendment relates to the Australian Meat and Livestock Research Development Corporation and will allow it to invest surplus funds that it has at any time. It is nice to know that a corporation such as this may have surplus funds to invest. I guess that with 18.5 per cent interest on offer for investments, that is a fairly attractive thing for the Corporation to be doing. I am pleased that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy is present and taking a keen interest in the debate on this legislation. I ask him: What is going on with live sheep exports to the Middle East? Why have hundreds of thousands of sheep exports worth $200m to $300m a year ceased? I wonder why it is that the Minister has not given up some of his valuable time to travel to the Middle East. I know that the Minister's opposite number in the Middle East took the opportunity to have a holiday just as the market crashed in a heap, but I would have thought that our Minister could have taken a bit of time off to travel to the Middle East to get this trade going again. It is most important for meat producers throughout Australia that this trade continue.

I turn now to the honey levy collection. There are many honey producers in the electorate of Maranoa who travel with their hives out to the Channel country and Cooper Creek chasing the best of flowering gums, and they do an excellent job. A lot of our honey is exported, although most of it is consumed locally. We produce some of the purest honey in the world. At the moment there is a lot of hype about conservation and pure food, but the honey producers in Australia produce some delicious sweet honey. The legislation will help simplify the collection of the levy, and I point out once again that everything that moves in this country has a levy on it. The honey producers levied themselves and, with the help of the Government, there was a monthly collection of the levy, if honourable members can imagine that. We receive a form on our desk every mail day now. If one has a farm in the bush one gets a form that has to be filled in. These poor honey producers have had to fill in a form every month to put in a return. If they are paying less than $100 a month and up to $1,200 a year, they only have to pay annually. At least the honey producers will save a few stamps and allow themselves to make a bit more net profit.

I turn now to soil conservation. Where is the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice)? He raves and rants in here. He took the opportunity of mentioning my name and electorate. Previously I have spoken in this House about the chemical graslan. This bloke has set himself up as some expert on graslan in the State of Queensland. The truth of the matter is that the chemical graslan was actually imported from America. It was tested by this Labor Government. The Federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy tested graslan for a number of years, as it does with other chemicals before their release. The Minister's Department tested this chemical for a number of years before deciding that it could be released. It was released to the States of Queensland and New South Wales and the Northern Territory. Those State primary industry departments then carried out extensive tests on the use of graslan.

I am still waiting for the honourable member for Hinkler to get into the chamber so that he can listen to me talk on this subject. It is amazing how he makes comments and then ducks for cover and shoots outside. This graslan chemical is the safest chemical we can use. It is made up into a clay pellet. There is no spray drift. Most chemicals that are used are sprayed out of aircraft. This chemical is distributed out of aircraft in pellet form. It is used to control regrowth and to allow our grasslands to maintain their production.

It is amazing how people are concerned about trees in Australia, but most parts of Australia are covered by eucalypts and woody weeds, brigalow suckers and eucalypt suckers. The more we knock them about, the thicker they grow. It does not matter what we do to them, we cannot kill them. This chemical has been imported. It has been used in America for the last 20 years at no detriment to anybody. It is an excellent chemical to use. I have used it myself. We could grab a handful of it and throw it under some regrowth, some brigalow suckers. They will slowly die over 12 months because the chemical goes through the ground into the root system as it rains. We hope that the things curl up and perish because the regrowth is the sort of stuff that we do not want when we are trying to run sheep and cattle. We are not running giraffes. Our stock do not feed from the tops of trees. They feed on grass. We need to thicken the grass to make a living. There is nothing wrong with the use of graslan.

The honourable member for Hinkler also mentioned drought aid to Queensland. Under a fair distribution of drought aid, when will Queensland get its share of drought aid. The Minister has cut off drought aid. The honourable member talks about drought. We are trying to conserve and save our productive sector for export. But as soon as there is mention of a bit of a rort on in Queensland-we have had an inquiry but nobody has been charged with the misuse of drought funds-this Government cuts off funds to Queensland entirely. We have had no drought aid at all for six or 12 months.

Where is the honourable member for Hinkler? He is still not in this chamber. In his speech he attacked the Queensland Government. He attacked the Minister, Neville Harper, for what he had done. Neville Harper set up the inquiry. We have looked at the drought aid problem and have come up with recommendations. Nobody has been charged with the misuse of funds. This Minister and this Government have still restricted the amount of funds that go to Queensland. They persecute us because we happen to have a National Party Government. I want to tell the Minister that the National Party in Queensland will continue to help primary producers in that State to preserve the cattle and sheep herds of Queensland, which are badly needed to boost the balance of payments with which this Labor Government has put us down the gurgler. We need as many exports as we can get.

I want to praise the Minister. I only hope that the breakthrough that we may be getting with the Americans on the subsidisation of grain comes to fruition, that we can continue to talk them out of the heavy subsidisation that takes place with their grain sales throughout the world. That also applies to Europe. I again mention the files and forms that appear on the desks of downtrodden farmers. The number of forms sent to barley producers has been reduced from 20 to four. I praise the Minister for this initiative. I certainly support this amendment. Those of us who run a farm or a small business are absolutely inundated. We practically have to employ a full time secretary these days to fill out all the forms that we receive from the Government as well as dealing with the questionnaires and levies we have to pay.

We have heard an awful lot about wheat and the Wheat Marketing Act of late. We have had long-winded debates in this House. I would like to point out to the Minister that Bulk Grains Queensland is asking for funds. It is $80m in debt. Since the wheat market has been deregulated, Bulk Grains and the grain growers of Queensland are finding it practically impossible to keep up the interest and redemption payments. I put it to the Minister that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his cohorts in Cabinet, Dawkins and company, are prepared to give Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd $30m or $40m just like that. The silver bodgie, the Prime Minister, represents that area. We are the battling farmers. The Government has deregulated the wheat industry. Eighty million dollars is owed. The Government can give the banks $200m. It is not as if the banks need help, for God's sake, but they got $200m to keep home loan interest rates down. Why could they not have given borrowers some of their profits? Why did the Government have to stitch up a deal with the banks and give them a bit more interest? Surely they could have paid the home-owners a bit out of the profits they have made. But no, the banks are not allowed to reduce their profit margins; they cannot do that. They have to have some special deal stitched up by the Treasurer. The poor wheat farmers' Queensland organisation is going bankrupt. It is $80m in debt. It has built this export facility in Brisbane. It is asking for help. What is the Federal Government doing? It is not doing a damned thing: not lifting a finger to help. That is the wheat part of the Bill covered, involving the transfer of funds for wheat research.

I turn to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act. That is doing away with-I hope-the import parity pricing policy. It was apparently terminated in 1987. There are four amendments relating to this that do away with it. That is the best thing that we ever did. I was always opposed to the Fraser-Anthony Government introducing import parity on our oil production. I thought it was the worst economic move that we ever made. I was proved right in the end; it has been abolished. Unfortunately, the tax that was collected can never be done away with. It was moved to the pump. It was moved from the well-head, and it is now taken into excise on fuel, on petrol. The excise tax paid on petrol is now 22c a litre. It has gone from 6c to 22c. At least it is better than the parity pricing, the iniquitous set-up where we tried to control the world price of oil. No sooner had we done that than the Arab group fell to pieces, and of course we fell to pieces as well because the income was not there. So the taxation was moved across to the pump. The Government had to do that to continue the welfare payouts. It is a pity it could not abolish the tax because the fuel industry in this country is super-taxed. I believe that the taxes on the industry ought to be reduced. If we are to remain self-sufficient in fuel, we have to take a very close look at the taxing regime and reduce it substantially. All this Government has done is increase it.

The main amendments in this Bill relate to the Wool Marketing Act. A number of members have spoken about this Act. I am still waiting for the honourable member for Hinkler to come in and listen to me. I do not know where he is. He has made all sorts of statements tonight but he has still not appeared again. I would be very grateful if he could lever himself off his couch and leave his can of beer to one side and come and listen to what I am saying.

The wool industry is our biggest industry. Last year it earned $5.4 billion in exports, which was 12.4 per cent of the total of $33 1/2 billion in Australian exports. Unfortunately for the Government, it is expected that the income from wool this year will be down to $4.2 billion. The Wool Corporation informed me that it will not be lowering the floor price. It has never been lowered and it is not the intention of the Corporation to lower it. It may have to maintain the floor price at its present level. It will be reviewed next June. The Corporation is absolutely emphatic in this regard, and it is important to tell the buyers of this product that the price of wool will not be lowered.

The floor price scheme is a great cost to our woolgrowers. Approximately $200m a year is collected from the growers and is put into a revolving fund. Recently, they were paid back a couple of hundred million dollars but each year the growers have to roll in another couple of hundred million and the fund is built up. The Corporation has actually spent over $1 billion in the last six months buying in 1.1 million bales of wool at a cost of about $1,000 a bale plus storage and interest.

The Wool Corporation has about $800m left to continue to buy in at the floor price. After that it has to borrow funds against the stockpile. It has a capital investment in the stockpile, about one-third of which is sent overseas. It is being stored in countries such as Japan for immediate sale to users. Until the wool is sold the value is not included in export income, but it is included from the moment it is sold.

Maranoa has many woolgrowers. Woolgrowing is one of the bigger industries in the electorate. It is of great concern to all of us that the price of wool has not remained as high as it should have for a longer period. If it had, many producers would have been able to overcome their economic problems. The wool industry still suffers the high interest rates of this Government but I will not divert on to that subject.

The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) made a very good speech last year about how high interest rates were. He was perfectly correct when he said that some producers were paying up to 27 per cent interest on the money required to stay in business. Australia is getting to the level of New Zealand because that is the sort of interest rate New Zealand producers have to pay to stay in business. As the honourable member for Gwydir said, it is an absolute disgrace that producers should be forced to pay 27 per cent interest. How can anybody pay such an interest rate and survive? They cannot.

Some good things have been happening in the wool industry. A very advanced artificial insemination (AI) centre was opened on 11 October on Haddon Rig stud, which is one of the leading studs in Australia. It produces fine wool and many sheep that are used locally and overseas. It is a great plus for the industry and I wish it every success in its new venture. It is not really a new venture; it is more of an extension of its operations. The AI centre was set up so that overseas buyers can purchase rams and hold them at the centre, and semen can be taken into quarantine and then exported. It is a very good development.

TALK.START.PARA: —The export of seamen is about coastal shipping reform, is it?

—It could be. No; efforts are made to fly it out using a Hercules, but that is difficult. The Minister is a little twisted about what sort of transport can be used. I assure him that there is no hope in the world that aircraft could have been used lately. This year $56m will be spent on wool research and development, which is very important to the industry not only in Australia but world wide.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to conclude by informing the House that next year the annual general meeting of the Corporation will be held in Roma, which is in the centre of my electorate. I point out, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the honourable member for Hinkler is still not in the House. It is just not good enough for a member of this House to criticise both Federal and State members of Parliament and not be here to listen to the Opposition putting up some fair and constructive arguments to counter the ridiculous statements that he makes in this place. I have much pleasure in supporting this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) indicated quite clearly why he has lost preselection. I would like to thank all honourable members who have spoken in the debate, including the honourable member for Maranoa, and I shall touch briefly on some of the comments made. The debate has ranged widely on this very large omnibus Bill. I thought that that was appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Most comments by honourable members related to the wool industry. I should like to join with honourable members, all of whom said that the wool floor price scheme is working very well and that they have total confidence in it. The present situation with the Australian Wool Corporation buying in duplicates occured on two previous occasions on which funds were applied to exactly the use for which they were accumulated. As the stockpiles were sold off on each occasion, the industry reaped quite a large gain. I am quite sure that the second half of the present wool selling season will see a different situation.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), quite rightly said that what is being done with wool research and development to some extent is a compromise. Basically the wool industry wanted to retain the status quo. I take the view that we cannot tolerate a situation in which some of the major recipients of wool research funding distribute the funds to themselves. There are real and distinct advantages in having research and development to some extent at arm's length from the marketing organisation. I believe sincerely that the wool industry is different inasmuch as the fact that there is an International Wool Secretariat means that the disbursement of funds and the clear links from marketing through to product development certainly assume a profile different from that in other industries.

Moving to a full corporation would certainly have had advantages to the industry, though we probably have the best of both worlds with an enhanced council. Moving to a corporation means moving into joint ventures, capitalising the benefits of any patents, and mobilising additional funds, and the management of such a research organisation has more flexibility. It can employ staff on more flexible conditions. By and large, in the papers accompanying the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on science and technology including research innovation and competitiveness we are setting out for the whole portfolio what principles should prevail, what the advantages are, and the various structures that we can erect. The Opposition tends to fail to look at principles at times; it picks up more acutely on the debate or the wishes of the various farm interest groups instead of looking at what the Government is on about, and making criticisms of that.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party made two statements which were simply untrue. The Government has not announced the termination of wool promotion in any final sense. What the wool industry now has is three years of assured funds and then another decision will be taken. I will not revisit history but all governments through time have had a problem with wool promotion. The razor gang in the infamous days of the Fraser-Howard Government slashed wool promotion back to $20m. It has always been subject to the whim of the fiscal fiend and quite frankly that is a disastrous approach. Wool promotion is one way of an Australian government saying where its earnest is as far as Australia's greatest export earning industry is concerned. We must look at this intellectually. As it is the only industry to which government gives money for promotion, it is somewhat inconsistent. But the wool industry has sufficient place in this country to warrant the continuation of wool promotion. If wool promotion is ever to be terminated, the industry has to be given a lot of notice of that.

The other claim by the Deputy Leader of the National Party to which I take exception is, to use his exact words, that there was tremendous pressure from the Australian Government on the Australian Wheat Board with respect to the Fisherman Island incident during the time that the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) was negotiating a package that could be put together for three months. I point out that WIRA is one person. I was certainly very much of the view that I should back very strongly the Government's position that we accepted the Inter-State Commission's advice, that WIRA had been established and that we were in the three-month period of negotiation. We now know what came out of that three-month period.

I put no pressure on the Board. I heard various rumours to the effect that the National Party Government in Queensland, the National Farmers Federation, Bulk Grains Queensland, Mr Ahern and Mr Harper were getting involved and were going to pull a stunt at Fisherman Island. I made an inquiry of the Chairman of the Wheat Board in the first instance to ask what was going on. He said he would get back to me, which he did. I pointed out that WIRA was being misrepresented. People were talking about the need for representation on WIRA when it comprised only one person. In another telephone conversation I simply spelt out the Government's position but issued no instruction. I said it was entirely up to the Wheat Board how it handled the matter. There have been further negotiations and the number of people at Fisherman Island has been reduced from six to two. I understand that various people in the industry want only one person to supervise the loading of ships at Fisherman Island. This will be a matter for industrial resolution.

The Deputy Leader of the National Party made another point with respect to the live sheep trade with Saudi Arabia. This issue is still so sensitive that I cannot go into all the details of it. It is my job to solve the problem rather than to blab about it and tell everyone every little detail I get to know about it. If the Opposition wishes to prove to the industry that it has the industry's interest at heart and is taking a keen interest in this issue, I am quite happy to affirm to the industry that the Opposition is as concerned about this matter as is the Government. But, if the Opposition wishes to embarrass the Government, I am afraid that I will simply take the view that I have taken and I will act on my judgment about all the professional advice I am getting on this issue. There is no sense in my going there. It would have been a positive impediment to resolution of the matter if I had gone to Saudi Arabia when the Minister was not there to talk to. It was not advised that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) should write to the King, the custodian of the two holy mosques, until we had an answer from the Minister for Agriculture and Water. That has now taken place and I believe, as does the industry-there has been a lot of consultation with the industry, including for nearly all of today-that we are handling this matter in a very professional manner.

I would not link the Prime Minister's involvement on the canned fruit issue with the Saudi live sheep issue. Canada is a different society from Saudi Arabia. Whenever any Minister is abroad, whether it be the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy) or me, we are all de facto Ministers for Trade in a way. It was very handy that the Prime Minister could take up the canned fruit issue with Prime Minister Mulroney.

The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) made quite a few comments about environmental matters. He touched on land degradation and drought assistance and referred to some of the scandals in Queensland. I give much credit to the honourable member for Hinkler because, had it not been for him, the waste of taxpayers' money by the Queensland Government on supposed drought assistance would have gone unnoticed. Quite frankly, I did not believe some of the allegations around. I was very much aware of the rumours. I have to deal in an ongoing fashion with whoever is my corresponding Minister in Queensland because we both act in the interests of the farmers of Queensland from the Commonwealth and State level.

The Queensland Public Accounts Committee unanimously reported that some $30m of taxpayers' money had been wasted on drought transport subsidies and that up to $300,000 went to some individual companies. That report was an indictment of the National Party administration, and was all the more damning because the report from the Committee was unanimous, and the majority of members of the Committee were members of the National Party. The report was explicitly critical of the administration of the previous Minister. But the Queensland National Party has not really learned anything from the report of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, from the Public Accounts Committee inquiry or anything else. There has simply been a series of manoeuvres by Sir Robert Sparkes to get rid of whichever Premier he does not want. Mr Harper attempted to answer the charges against him. He ignored three of the Committee's five criticisms. His answer to the other two is that Queensland Ministers are allowed to treat public servants as arbitrarily as they like and to spend the money as they like.

I have to deal with other Queensland Ministers in other forums. It is really sad to see people in that Government who simply do not understand the issues of accountability that apply to Ministers and members on both sides of this House. They seem to think that one can have a hillbilly dictatorship and that that is the way things are played. As I have said, it is quite sad. The standard of public administration accepted by the new Queensland Premier is pretty bad. The new Minister for Primary Industries-I have not met him yet-went around the State asking those who would have benefited from the waste of money what they thought. Surprise, surprise! They did not want any change. So the Queensland Government has decided to continue the policies; nothing has changed. The argument is that the Public Accounts Committee's recommendations would damage the grazing industry. That is nonsense. Only a small proportion of graziers benefit from the waste of money, and they are mainly the big pastoral companies. The pastoral industries in other States get along satisfactorily without that sort of waste. Other States handle the matter with decency and honesty-not maladministration. That is why we acted against the Queensland Government's waste of money by taking drought out of the natural disaster relief arrangements and establishing a task force to report to me on long term drought policy early next year.

While our long term drought policy will depend on the task force's report, we will certainly not be paying any more money to the Queensland Nationals while they are so corrupt and hopeless at administration. When we hear of things like this, is it any wonder that the farmers in Queensland are backing the Australian Labor Party? The only hope for that State is for it to get a Labor government after all these years of crooked government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will see!

—Well, I would like to bring a copy of the Fitzgerald report in here one night and tell honourable members how Joh got his dam and his road and about Ciasom Pty Ltd, the company that he set up. There have been years and years of corruption and maladministration. As I have said, the really sad thing is that some of the time members of the National Party were so stupid that they really did not know what they were doing in terms of principles. My colleague the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding), who is sitting beside me tonight, and I look around outside our door every day for paper bags full of money. SPEECH.PARA: I thank the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), who has exhibited the continuing interest of the previous honourable member in matters rural. His was a magnificent contribution.
