TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1989 concurrently with the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills under discussion are the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1989 and the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989. It might be helpful if I dispose of the latter Bill first. As far as the Opposition is concerned, that Bill is largely unexceptional and we are prepared to support it. The Bill itself is really a matter of tidying up certain amendments relating to the Overseas Students Charge Act. Those amendments are consequential upon the passing of the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989 but, because it was a tax Act, the original amendments could not be made in the former Bill; they have to be made separately. Thus this Bill contains a clause to amend the definition of `overseas student' to reflect amendments previously made in the Migration Legislation Amendment Act 1989. For consistency, we are more than happy to support that Bill. I think it should be noted that, in this legislation and in the other Bill, essentially we will be dealing with tidying up exercises where certain defects have been found in the drafting. Clearly, some amendments were made to the Overseas Students Charge Act that would have been ineffective. They would have been ineffective simply because it was not done in a separate Bill, as required.

SPEECH.PARA: The second and more substantial piece of legislation is the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill. Again, this Bill will make a number of amendments-people like to use these words-to correct unintended operations of that Act and to satisfy the promise made to me by the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Holding) during debate on that legislation. It is that latter matter, which is the most substantial aspect of this legislation, that I will be addressing.

In order that my discussion might be complete, let me note that the main provisions of this legislation concern the definition of a properly endorsed entry visa that is to be inserted in the Act. At the moment there is only a definition of `properly endorsed valid entry permit' while entry under visa is allowed on pre-checked flights. Under section 9 of the principal Act this amendment will allow the visa to be endorsed overseas, and it is to amend section 11 of the principal Act to place people entering under such a document in the same position as a non-citizen who may become an illegal entrant due to providing false or misleading information. Amendments under new section 11e aim to enable the quick issue of tourist visas. In new subsection (18) and section 20 certain amendments require people making decisions under those sections to consider only prescribed matters and it is aimed to promote consistency. The power to arrest a person who has escaped from custody will be made clear in amendments to paragraph 17 (n) of the principal Act and the principal Act will be amended to allow a regulation to fix fees to be charged for English language tests.

As I have said, the most substantial matter involves an amendment to subsection 17a (2) of section 8 of the principal Act, which provides that the Minister must deport an illegal immigrant if satisfied that the person is liable for deportation. It is known as the mandatory deportation provision and it has been a fairly controversial question. The amendment will require the Minister to follow prescribed procedures before becoming satisfied that the person is eligible for deportation. This amendment aims to address certain difficulties arising from the removal of ministerial discretion in certain cases.

The Minister in his explanation during the second reading debate said that during the passage of the amendment Act concerns were expressed by the Opposition that it was possible, under its provisions, that a person recognised by Australia as a refugee could unintentionally be expelled by being deported or being required to depart. The Minister noted that he gave assurances that this would not be able to occur. He said that to ensure that those legitimate concerns are put to rest and his assurances kept, provision is to be made for procedures and criteria for the exercise of powers of expulsion and for that to be prescribed in regulation. That is the explanation of the substantial matter that we are dealing with.

I simply want to note here that I do regard it as important that, where there are exceptional circumstances of a compassionate or humanitarian kind which affect particularly refugees, it would be absolutely preposterous if mandatory deportation provisions were actioned and a Minister could not stop that procedure if it were put in place by some accident or omission on the part of officers. The Minister believed that he would be able to do that when he gave me the assurance. He believed that he would be able to ensure that nobody would be deported if they had valid refugee claims or if there were proper compassionate circumstances. Of course, what he has found, presumably on advice now, is that that view he had was wrong. It shows a certain inadequacy in the preparation of this matter, I suspect, because it was one of considerable comment. But I am pleased that he has endeavoured to honour the undertaking that he gave. New subsection 17a (2) of section 8 deals with that matter. Essentially, it is very simple. The new subsection states:
Insert ``, after following the prescribed procedures,'' after ``Minister'' (first occurring).
It is also proposed that new subsection 18 (1) be added to section 8. The new subsection states:
Insert ``, after considering the prescribed matters and no other matters,'' . . .

I want to make a number of points in relation to that and I would seek certain assurances from the Minister as to the way in which this question is going to be addressed. At the moment the explanation is that the Minister is going to prescribe certain procedures that have to be followed and certain questions that will have to be asked by officers before this mandatory deportation provision is actioned. Presumably, if those procedures are not followed, a person would be able to seek redress before a court to ensure that he was not deported. There is a further embargo. It is proposed to insert after `Minister', presumably the decision maker, the words:
`, after considering the prescribed matters and no other matters,' . . .

This is a matter that I think needs to be looked at. We are in a situation where we are going to consider putting in place a procedure when we have not yet seen what are to be the prescribed procedures to be followed. In other words, the regulatory framework is not before us. Yet, the courts which are to deal with these matters are being told that no matters are to be entertained other than those dealt with by the prescribed procedures.

The Opposition does not wish to deny passage to this legislation. But I would again seek from the Minister either an undertaking that those regulations will be made available to us before the Senate has finished dealing with this legislation or, alternatively, his assurance that these matters will be properly referred to the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that that will occur.

—This is the committee that is looking at the reasonableness of these provisions. I note that the Minister interjected and said that he believes that that is to occur. I welcome that assurance because it seems to me that the kernel of this matter is the way in which the regulations themselves are framed and the extent to which there are proper protections where this very onerous provision operates. As I say, I thank the Minister for his comment and I assume that it will be put in the form of an undertaking when he responds.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a number of other brief comments in relation to the shape of this legislation that we are amending. When the legislation was before the House previously, a number of points were the subject of very considerable discussion. One of them-because we are putting in place a regulatory framework-involved the question of ministerial discretion. One of the compromises that were reached between the Opposition and the Government was that where the words `the Secretary' were used in legislation the words `the Minister' were substituted. The purpose of that was to ensure that ministerial discretion, where discretion was to exist in the migration legislation, would be maintained.

The Opposition regarded that question as being of a threshold nature. Yet, it does appear that there is some confusion in the minds of the Government and its advisers as to what has been done. I note that during the hearings of Estimates Committee E on 28 September 1989 the Minister's adviser, Mr Gibbons, was asked to comment on certain publications that were being made available and the money that was being appropriated for the provision of them. Senator Durack questioned Mr Gibbons about the broad parameters that were to be followed in relation to the recasting and rewriting of immigration procedures and pamphlets. Mr Gibbons said:

The rationale is that there has been a radical change to the migration law which comes into force on 19 December. That involves a shift from the situation where the Minister has absolute discretion to one where he has none unless the law, in the form of regulations, provides it. All the rules for immigration decision making are being made in regulations. Those rules provide that the applicant be told up-front precisely what the law is and what the guidelines on administering any areas of discretion admitted in the law are. There is a need to produce instruction manuals for our staff and information material for our clients and revise every form that we use . . .

I want to make it very clear that my understanding is that the very reason we have the Migration Regulations Committee is to examine those regulations to ensure that the discretion to deal with compassionate and humanitarian circumstances which exist in policy now is put in place in this regulatory framework. So I am concerned when it is suggested that a considerable shift occurred when this legislation was promulgated. The only shift so far as I am concerned is that the discretion has to be set out in the regulatory framework and that the discretion that the Minister has had will be maintained.

I recently had drawn to my attention a letter that was written by the Minister's private secretary. I do not know whether it is a confidential letter. The person who received it gave it to me. But the Minister's private secretary seems to be perpetuating this view. I want to quote a paragraph from that letter. He said:

You have suggested discretionary powers to take account of such situations. You will be aware that as a result of recent changes to the Migration Act, policies on applications for entry and for residence are currently being enacted into regulations. These will guide decision makers in applying the provisions of the Act in a consistent and fair manner. It is not expected however that the regulations will result in discretionary provisions of the kind you propose. Such discretionary provisions would also be at odds with Australia's non-discriminatory migration policy. To allow for special consideration for one group of applicants would go against this fundamental principle of Government policy.

I must say that in this case the gentleman concerned was asking for certain special account to be taken of the circumstances of those who were victims of oppression in Iran. He was putting forward characteristics of a humanitarian kind for which special provision might be made. Yet the Minister's private secretary says that there will be no scope for this under the changes to the Migration Act. As I understand it, special provisions are already in place in relation to people from the Lebanon. Nobody has said that that is at odds with Australia's non-discriminatory migration policy. The fact is that the matter that is taken into account is that of humanitarian considerations. One would believe that a judgment would be made as to whether or not special account should be taken of the circumstances in other countries. But that has nothing to do with discrimination in terms of race, religion or anything else of that character.

I am concerned that there appears to be a view-and it has been put to people by the Minister's office-that there will not be a capacity to deal with characteristics of a humanitarian or compassionate kind. That goes against the thrust of Government policy as I have understood it over time and the regulations which a committee of this Parliament has been asked to review against that policy. I would hope that the Minister would ensure that the comments of his senior advisers and the correspondence from his office reflect the decisions and agreements that were reached in this Parliament leading to the establishment of a committee and the decisions that were reached whereby the legislation was allowed to pass with certain amendments.

Honourable members will be aware that the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill sought to enact certain provisions relating to the regulation of migration agents. The provisions were in two parts: they repealed the provisions that formerly existed in the Act and they dealt with the definition of migration agents; the requirement to notify the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs of the intention to work as a migration agent; the Minister's express powers to direct that persons cannot act as migration agents; the provision setting out maximum charges that can be demanded by migration agents; the requirement to furnish fees to authorised officers of the Department on request; and the requirement to provide passage or make passage arrangements for non-citizens within specified time limits.

The Minister in his second reading speech commented that those provisions were outdated and he put in place what I would call consumer protection provisions which put the onus on a party who has a complaint with a migration agent to pursue new remedies which are created under the Act. I must say that when I looked at those provisions at the time it did not seem to be unreasonable to make that change. The new provisions created a new offence, where migration agents claim that they can influence decision making by certain officers, either by themselves or through a third person. They also made migration agents more accountable to their clients, giving them two important consumer rights-that is, the right to receive a detailed statement of services performed and their charges, and the right to seek reparation of losses incurred where a migration agent commits an offence against division 6 of the Act. The explanatory memorandum to those provisions noted that this right to seek damages would be the most effective control of the actions of migration agents.

At that time I was not aware of some of the complaints that have now come to my attention about the conduct of immigration agents. I notice that the Minister has issued a press release in which he has warned people, counselled people, that they should be on their guard in relation to the activities of immigration agents. But it seems to me that a lot of very undesirable activities are occurring and they are of a character which demand the attention of this Parliament. I would go further and suggest that the Minister needs to review the provisions that he put in place in this legislation and to do so before it is proclaimed on 19 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should be harder; they should be tougher.

—I hear the honourable member's comments. The Minister may care to note them. During our consideration of the estimates for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, I asked the Minister what efforts have been taken to use the existing provisions for controlling the activities of immigration agents. I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Will the Government be relying on clients only to seek redress under amendments to the Immigration Act or to use consumer protection law? I raise that question relating to agents in the context of illegal immigration because of the large number of complaints that are now coming to notice of large amounts of money being paid to individuals holding themselves out to assist people with applications for a change of status. The distinct probability is that those people holding themselves out to assist are not able to do so and very large amounts of money are being lost to individuals because of those representations. It seems that, notwithstanding an increase in the numbers of illegal immigrants located . . . there was still a net increase in the number of overstayers . . .
The point I was making then was that problems were arising. The separate questions that I posed do not appear to have been answered by the Minister.

It seems to me that the Department has been able to formulate a procedure for the accreditation of migration consultants to service business migrants. It has done so by contract. Certain fees are charged. I have seen copies of the agreements. A very comprehensive scrutiny is involved. The only basis upon which applications can be submitted by such people on behalf of clients is if the agent is registered. So there is very close supervision. The licensing of consultants who service the rich is quite comprehensive, but the regulation of the agents who service the poor is almost non-existent. The point needs to be made that those people who use migration agents in general are the ones who most need protection. They tend to be the illiterate, the poor, the people who have little command of English. Often they are frantic to seek assistance because of their lack of expertise and, I might say, the inability of departmental officers to provide adequate assistance.

I know that officers are cautious about offering advice, particularly after the Shaddock and Parramatta Council case in which some personal liability might be incurred. Members of Parliament should consider that when constituents go to their offices. We give advice and counsel in circumstances where people cannot get advice and counsel from the Department. We produce forms and information for people to read, but very often they lack the capacity to do so. So they seek an explanation from other people who, in many cases, are not qualified to offer it. People are now holding themselves out to be advisers and some are solicitors. Generally speaking, solicitors are licensed by their respective law societies. Incompetence and dishonesty should be dealt with by their professional bodies. I still hold a practising certificate and I would not want to reflect upon any colleagues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—There are certain ethics in relation to these matters. Nevertheless, some are not as expert as others and that is a matter of concern to me. Maybe what we need in this area is what is being encouraged in family law, whereby people who have some expertise can be put on an appropriate list or referred to by law societies, or whatever, in respective States. However, there are others who have no particular training but who hold themselves out to be agents.

SPEECH.PARA: There are numerous complaints. I refer honourable members to some newspaper articles I have seen. Only recently there was in the Australian an article under the byline of Adam Courtenay headed, `Scared Chinese ripped off in migration rorts'. Somebody from my office has gone through the circumstances mentioned in that article with the people involved. Certainly, prima facie, large numbers of Chinese students are being forced to pay large sums of money, even though they are counselled in their newspapers and the like not to do so. There are people advertising in newspapers who are holding themselves out as agents and creating fear. There is one advertisement in the Daily Telegraph which states:
Overstayed students or visitors
This may be your last chance
Recently the Federal Government approved an amendment to the Migration Act. . .these amendments are expected to become law in December
One of the Section will cover persons who are overstayed and automatic deportation is intended against you
Talk to [us] now!!!

People then get into those offices and in many cases there are no independent witnesses. They are asked to pay money up front and certain representations are made. No receipts are issued and there is little evidence that the offence that this Act says is likely to lead to prosecution has been established; the Department would not be able to deal with it. But the reports are legion.

The large number of people advertising their services in a way which preys upon people under great stress embarrasses me. Not so long ago it was occurring amongst the Fijian Indians who had made their way to Australia after the coup. Now, after the massacre in China, people are holding themselves out as agents to offer advice. A certain agent in Sydney has told his clients that as a result of the Chinese massacre only 3,000 students will be able to stay as permanent residents and that he has the capacity to squeeze students into this quota, provided they pay for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't a lawyer, was it?

—No, it was not a lawyer. Another student was charged $5,000, of which $1,500 was non-refundable, to process an application for permanent residency. The charge of $3,475 was made to process the application for change of status. These matters are of concern to me and they should be of concern to all honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: What troubles me is that the capacity of the Department to act in these matters appears most limited. I suspect that, notwithstanding what the Minister has said in his press release about encouraging people to be wary, we are in a situation where his power to assist is extremely limited and those people who are being ripped off will not be able to obtain redress.

I do not seek additional regulation, but it seems to me that, where it is required, it ought to be looked at in a constructive way. I am very concerned about what is happening in this area. It is the Chinese students who are now being exploited. When we look at the way in which we responded to the massacre in Tiananmen Square we can appreciate why we ought to be very conscious that they not be ripped off in the way which is occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), raised a number or questions in relation especially to the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill. The most profitable thing that can be done is to try to deal with some of the problems that he has raised. I make the general observation that these problems are more apparent than real. We are in the process of putting into place probably the biggest changes in the migration system and in the Migration Act for 40 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member said that he would like an assurance that certain regulations will go to the Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations for consideration. He is a member of that Committee, of which I have the honour of being the Chairman. The fact is that we are considering a huge amount of regulations that have come out of the previous Act. The point about those regulations is that they are intended to put into place an entirely new approach to the immigration system. The approach which they are putting into place is that, whereas previously many issues were left to subjective judgment on the basis of rules that were given to various immigration officers which they could follow if they chose to or, if they chose to ignore, could justify, now we will have a much more objective international system.

This is a very important point because that objective international system is intended to make the immigration program a non-discriminatory program around the world. It is intended that those criteria apply, as far as is humanly possible, equally around the world. The various marks that will be given in the points system will be put into the computer, which will then put them into the pool. Then at a given moment-every six months in the first year and every four months in the second and consequent years-the computer will choose from that pool the number determined as the total number going through the immigration system. We have a completely new approach, a completely new objective process, in immigration.

In that context, naturally when the Act and the regulations were drafted, one might have imagined that there would be some areas which required further legislation or further amendment. That is what this Bill does. The shadow Minister ought not reflect on either the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs or the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), both of whom have done a massive job in putting together the new policy, the new Act, the new rules, the new handbooks and now the new regulations. An enormous job had to be done.

Naturally, there are areas which needed further clarification. This does not reflect badly on the Department; I think it reflects well on the Department and on the Minister that we have already identified some problem areas even before the Act goes into place on 19 December. I reject the comments of the honourable member for Dundas that there are inadequacies in the Department. This is not an inadequacy; it is simply the recognition that an enormous job has had to be done. In the process of doing that job we have identified certain areas that needed further clarification and further legislation, and that is what we are about to do.

The shadow Minister, the honourable member for Dundas, referred to assurances that he had received about the procedures in relation to mandatory deportation provisions. He was basically saying: Will there be new regulations consequent upon this legislation becoming law? The answer to that is yes. The new regulations will be supplementary to the regulations which are being considered at present by the Migration Regulations Committee. The further regulations that will come up will most likely-subject to the matter being further looked at by the Minister and his approval-go before the Migration Regulations Committee in its next phase of considerations, after it has considered the existing regulations which have just come before it in penultimate form. The answer is that there will be new regulations within this framework in relation to the mandatory deportation provisions. That is a very good thing. The new regulations will specify the procedures which the Minister will go through and will probably be considered by the Migration Regulations Committee in order to ensure that they meet the various considerations.

There is also the question of whether a residual power will reside with the Minister in relation to exceptional circumstances which might come to his attention. As far as I understand it, the answer again on this point is yes; but if the Minister makes a determination under such a provision, then he is required to specify reasons for such a determination before the Senate. That is required under the procedures before the House of Representatives. As I understand it, when the Minister makes a provision which is outside the bounds of the regulations themselves, he is required to make a special statement in relation to that in the Senate or the House of Representatives.

That brings me to the next point raised by the shadow Minister in relation to the discretion of the Minister. The honourable member made many points. He said, `If we can have special provisions for the people of the Lebanon, how come the Minister cannot have discretion to deal with, for example, the situation in Iran, or if, say, something else breaks out in another part of the world where humanitarian considerations might come into play, why cannot the Minister have discretion in relation to that?'. I think what has happened here is that the word `discretion' is being bandied about a little bit in a number of contexts.

I believe that the shadow Minister took out of context parts of the letter from which he read. He tried to maintain that, if in some part of the world a situation arose which required special action by the Minister, then the Minister would not have the ability to deal with that situation. That is not correct; the Minister would be able to deal with it. In that situation the Minister can bring down regulations of the kind which we are considering in relation to the people of the Lebanon. What are we doing with the Lebanon situation? We have specific regulations to deal with that case. If a special situation arises in another part of the world which requires further determinations, then we will bring down another set of regulations to deal with those specific instances. That is the way in which the Minister has a discretion-to use the term of the honourable member for Dundas-to deal with a special problem.

It is not as if the Minister does not have a power to deal with exceptional situations; but where the Minister does not have a discretion is in not being able to overthrow the regulations and act independently of the regulations, except in the special cases I mentioned where he tables an explanation in the House of Representatives or the Senate in relation to that. So the Minister does have an additional discretion in certain cases to go outside the regulations, but that only when the Minister can table the reasons.

The issue that was raised by the honourable member for Dundas has been, continues to be, and can be, dealt with by either the promulgation of additional regulations in relation to a specific group or, if the Minister feels, for example, that there is not enough time for the promulgation of such regulations, he would be able to deal with it by making an explanation in the House of Representatives or the Senate. I believe that those two issues which have been raised by the shadow Minister are capable of being dealt with and can be dealt with by the procedures which have been adopted.

I want to say something about the shadow Minister's comments in relation to migration agents. I think every member of the House would share the concern that he has about migration agents and people who pretend to be able to do things for migrants, whether or not they are registered agents. As honourable members will know, under the new rules there will be no registration of agents except in the business migration area. We are all concerned about people who purport to be agents or purport to be able to help people and then rip them off. That is precisely why new legislation has been introduced-because we want to be able to deal with this problem.

The shadow Minister pointed to examples which have applied in the past, about which we are concerned, but I remind him that the new rules will not be put into place until 19 December. After 19 December, very tough provisions will be in place. First, people who consider themselves to be ripped off by a migration agent or anyone purporting to help them in immigration matters will be able to deny payment to that person. They will have the full support of the law in making such a denial. In other words, the onus will be on the person who purports to be an agent to prove or to show that the service has been delivered. The onus will not be on the person to whom the service has been delivered. Secondly, if money has been paid to such a person, an application can be made to a court that misrepresentation has taken place and the court will be able to make restitution to that person. There is a consumer-type protection for people who have been ripped off by migration agents or people purporting to be able to help them in immigration matters.

Similarly, there will be provisions for the punishment of people who misrepresent claims. I refer, for example, to people who try to give guaranteed assurances that they can help people to remain in Australia, or people who suggest that they have a special method of approaching officers of the Department, the Minister or a member of parliament in such a way that they are able to assure or guarantee that that person will be successful in his immigration application. That kind of misrepresentation will be punishable; it will be considered to be a criminal offence. Those are the two aspects: there will be redress on the consumer side and there will be redress on the other side in terms of criminal offences.

I find it extraordinary that the honourable member for Dundas should suggest that these provisions are insufficient, yet he did not suggest what additional provisions might be possible or necessary in order to assist the situation. He seemed to be suggesting that we should return to some system of registration of people who purport to be agents. But there are two problems with that. Any provision to protect people, including the poor-and he talked about protecting the poor-would apply only to the registered agents. Under the new rules, anyone, whether he is registered or not, who purports to help a migrant and who takes money for that purpose is subject to those rules. So a much broader spectrum of people is covered than would be covered under a registration system. Anybody who is ripped off by a person promising to help them in immigration matters will be covered by this law. The suggestion that we should have some system of formal registration in a sense defeats the purpose and would make the situation more narrow. So we reject that approach.

We suggest that anyone who purports to assist a migrant, anyone who takes money for helping a migrant, will be open to these provisions and could be punishable. We strongly support that approach unless and until either a better approach is generated or is shown to be able to work or an alternative is brought up which can deal with problems that may arise after 19 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want us to do your work for you?

—That is not what we want. We do not want you to do the work for us. What we are saying is: wait until 19 December and after, see how these rules-which are much tougher, in our opinion-apply, and then, if there are gaps or problems in relation to the rules, I am sure that the Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories and Minister Assisting the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding), and the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), the Minister in the other place, will both be ready to consider any further tightening or further amendments. The approach that has been taken here is much better than what previously existed because now we are able to cover any kind of situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember the situation which used to exist. A case came to my attention involving a welfare worker-not a registered agent in any sense-in an ethnic community. When people talked to him about immigration problems, he asked them to pay him money and promised to help them. If we had a registration system, we probably could not cover that sort of person because he would not seek to be registered. But under this legislation, such a person would be covered. This person had the gall to go to various members of parliament and ask them to make representations for people, claiming to be a welfare worker. Unbeknown to the members of parliament, that person was collecting money from the clients concerned. It was only when a particular case failed that the matter came to our attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not an isolated case, either.

—As the honourable member says, it is not an isolated case. In fact, it was shown that the only thing that could be done in that case was to try to use moral persuasion to get the money back for the people concerned. There was no provision in the Act at that time to deal with this person in terms of criminal offences. Under the new provision, that person would be subject to criminal offence provisions and could face criminal charges.

SPEECH.PARA: So the provisions that we have drafted take account of all the matters raised by the honourable member for Dundas. I welcome this legislation, as I welcomed the earlier legislation in relation to the Migration Act. Let us all get together in the spirit of bipartisanship that has existed so far to try to eradicate whatever problems can be located and to get the most objective and the most revolutionary, in a sense, Migration Act operating in a proper way for the future of this country. There is no doubt that this Act and the previous Act together are seen as a model for the rest of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is frequently said by this Government, especially by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that it is the best government that the country has ever seen. I think that in some of his better moments he probably thinks that it is the best government that the world has ever seen. Today, in Question Time, in reference to the environment, children or whatever, he said that his Government's record was the best record of any government in the world. We are accustomed to these imaginings. It would be curious to find the Prime Minister actually confronting some of the realities that exist in this country. He prefers to deal with things which exist in some far off country to be found in his mind, such as the non-existent airline pilots dispute. We know, of course, that there is none. We only have to travel around the country to realise that.
—I am loath to interrupt the honourable member but I ask whether he intends to direct his remarks to the Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill.

—Yes, I certainly am. I will address my remarks to an issue that arises out of the Overseas Student Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2). Students are people and people can be hurt. This Government has, by its recent actions in respect of Chinese students, deliberately-because it cannot have been done by oversight-set out to hurt, to damage, a group of people who have no redress at all, people who have gone through the painful process of getting together money so that they could come to study English in Australia. The changes came about in a way which, on the face of it, was perfectly innocuous. A statement was made on behalf of the Government on 30 August this year by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins), and by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray). In that statement procedures and criteria for the People's Republic of China's English language students were set out. They were altered. The relevant part of this notice states:

SPEECH.PARA: The backlog of 25,000 applications in the People's Republic of China wishing to undertake English language courses will be asked to fill in a questionnaire, and these applicants will then be assessed against the following criteria:
they must have a minimum educational level to the Australian standard Year 10;
a maximum age of 35 years;

they must present some form of certification of the relevance of the course to their current employment, or demonstrated relevance to future employment, or evidence of provisional enrolment in appropriate further education.

This was done against the background of Tiananmen Square. This was done against a known and stated backlog of 25,000 applicants. This was done-we are not talking about blocks of wood-in respect of people who had, at great trouble to themselves, got together the money up-front for the purposes of English language tuition in Australia. English language tuition in Australia was to be their entry into a better life. As I understand it $5,000 must be paid up-front before a visa application can be submitted.

I take one example from the literature on this subject and I think that everybody in this House would have read some of it. We know that there have been large protests around our consulate in Shanghai and the reasons are very simple. Many people feel that they have been treated wrongly, unjustly and harshly by this Government. I refer to the case of a Mr Chen as reported in the Age of 11 September 1989. The article states:

Mr Hawke wept when he said (after the 4 June massacre of democracy protesters) that the Chinese people were bleeding. Does he not realise we are also bleeding in the heart because of what he has done.

This is Mr Chen's story. He had to borrow $5,000 to attend a short term English course in Australia and he now finds that he does not meet the new criteria. He is afraid to go back to his pregnant wife in Shanghai. He was forced to leave his mechanics job after acceptance into a Sydney language school in March. Having lost his job he can earn about $A36 a month. According to the article, his wife is at breaking point. The money that Mr Chen has to pay, for a man in his position, is just alarming. To get the $US4,700 to study in Sydney, he had to borrow on the open market. That cost him about $A12,925. It is higher, or course, because he could not deal in the official rate; he had to deal in the unofficial exchange rate. Add on to that some other costs and his commitment comes out at $A15,250. Presuming that the Sydney school returns all of the $US4,700 he has paid, he will find himself with a deficit of $A10,910. That is a huge debt for a person in his situation-a debt that he will never be able to repay.

Mr Chen is but one example of many people in this situation. What are the reasons for this? Why was the change made so shortly after Tiananmen Square? Why were the changes made retrospectively and were known to operate retrospectively? Was it to guard against the risk of students overstaying? That could be guarded against in different ways. Does one think that simply because students are under the age of 35 years they will be less likely to overstay? On the contrary, I should have thought that the younger they were the more likely they would be to overstay. What will happen to this man and to people like him? The truth of the matter is that they are in the most grievous and sad of circumstances. We have seen great expressions of compassion by this Government. We have seen the Prime Minister looking at the cameras telegenically and weeping the odd tear or two, and we have seen him weeping the odd tear or two over Tiananmen Square.

TALK.START.PARA: —That dispute is over, like the pilots dispute!

—That dispute is over, as my colleague says, like the pilots dispute! The Prime Minister has wrung as much out of it as he could. Who gives a damn about these poor people? They are only Chinese, they do not vote, they are sitting in China, their hopes are nil, their prospects nil and their situation is desperate. At the very least, if the Government is going to change the rules of the game retrospectively, as it has done on so many occasions, it could do the decent thing by these people and make sure that somehow they are financially compensated for the outlays that they have incurred in the hope that the same rules would apply as applied at the time when the money was handed over.

SPEECH.PARA: If you allow money to be handed over and after it is handed over, knowing the effect and the changes that it will have on the people who have handed it over, you do things which have perfectly disastrous consequences on individuals, then what you are doing is wrong and immoral. But one would not expect anything different from this Government. It is a sad story. It is a story that I think most people around here would consider to be sad. Yet, nothing will be done about it unless the Government has a few second thoughts. But why should anyone have a few second thoughts about people who do not have a vote? That is all I wish to say on that issue.

I now mention one other matter, and that is the position of those who act as agents for persons who wish to settle in this country or who may be here and wish to stay. It is understandable that people should take advice and it is understandable that people want to explore all kinds of avenues. I suppose that nobody can object to people performing a service and getting a fair fee, but in this area we have to look very carefully at people who proffer advice and who exact very considerable fees from individuals who may feel they are not in a position to strike a fair bargain and thus must accept whatever rate is put to them. When that happens one cannot say that they have had a free choice. I do not suggest that all who proffer advice are in this position, but one can say that in some cases such people have been unfairly taken advantage of. That is something that we should make sure does not take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Realising the lateness of the hour, I will endeavour to be brief. The Migration Legislation Amendment (Consequential Amendments) Bill and the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill (No. 2) deal with very complex legislation which is related to the Migration Act 1989. It is understandable, as the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) suggested, that there should be some revision, some clarification and perhaps some improvement and changes as a consequence of the passing of that legislation. As I said, this is very complex legislation. It is the sort of legislation that everybody is trying to drive a truck through. It has been the case with migration legislation in this country that for many years there has been a great deal of concern about the way in which it has been possible to slip and slide past the regulations and past the Act. The fact that we have 50,000 to 70,000 illegal immigrants in Australia is an indication of that. It is very difficult to police this legislation as well as one would like.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that the contributions of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) have influenced me to say one or two things. Indeed, the honourable member for North Sydney suggested that it was unacceptable that Australia should place some sort of criteria on those who choose to come to Australia from the People's Republic of China to learn English. He suggested that it is unacceptable that we should require that there should be a minimum requirement for an educational status of Year 10, that it is unacceptable that we should ask that the maximum age requirement for these people be 35 years; that it is unacceptable that they should have to certify that in some way their study of English is relevant to their job or occupation, and indeed that they should be able to provide evidence of provisional enrolment. I would say that it is absolute humbug on the part of the Opposition to suggest that.

The honourable member for North Sydney is sitting on the back bench now because he is one of those who supported the line put by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) some time ago in this House which suggested that Australia had every right to determine the criteria for immigration and for visas for those who wished to enter this country and that Australia should proclaim that right and make it clear. For some reason that same person is suggesting that it is unreasonable to provide those sorts of conditions. We have 15,000 students from China who have sanctuary in this country until July next year. I imagine that the honourable member would support the view that Margaret Thatcher takes, knowing his political position, about those Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong, whether they be real refugees or economic refugees, who are being sent back to Vietnam. It is the sovereign right of the United Kingdom to take that position, and he would support it. But there is no sovereign right for Australia to apply those sorts of criteria and conditions as to who gets a visa to come to Australia. I find that very difficult to comprehend, and inconsistent. I suppose I should not be surprised because it was put forward by the honourable member for North Sydney. He comes in here with a bleeding heart for the Chinese after he supported the position put by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) when he was Leader of the Opposition. I know and respect the position of the honourable member for Dundas, who did not support that view. He took a completely honourable and moral stance on that issue. I say to those in the Opposition that they should be consistent about these things. We did not raise this issue. The honourable member for Dundas came in here and raised it.

The other two issues are seminal to the legislation. The first is that of ministerial discretion. It should be understood that ministerial discretion still exists. We have separated the criteria. Once there is a suggestion that someone wishes to appeal, then there are two appeal processes within the legislation. At that stage the Minister has discretion. The only difference from that which existed previously is that it requires the Minister to come to this place and justify his decision. Those who come into this House and plead for privilege and for the position whereby there should be unfettered discretion for the Minister, so there can be hand- outs and favours all around the country for members of parliament who have access to the Minister and for nobody else, do not seem to realise that it is inconsistent. It is inequitable, it is not objective and it is not fair. It is perfectly reasonable that we should curtail that discretion which previously existed for the Minister and to bring in some decency in the way this system operates. That is what we are trying to do with this legislation. We are trying to remove that unfettered discretion which led to privileges for members of parliament and some sections of the community who had access to the Minister but there was no fairness for many other groups.

What we are suggesting is perfectly reasonable. I think the honourable member for Dundas understands that within the regulations there will be considerable discussion and toing and froing until we reach a reasonable compromise through consultation. When that procedure has finished we will be in a position where, when decisions are taken on immigration, the Minister will have discretionary power. But we are requiring him to come in here and justify it before the House. That tightens it up. It makes it fairer and more objective. I think it is something that people will appreciate when they consider this issue.

The third issue that was raised and canvassed by the honourable member for Dundas and the honourable member for North Sydney was that of consultants-the immigration advisers who see themselves as migration agents and have over a period of time had the opportunity to take advantage of people who were in very difficult circumstances and in need of advice and assistance, people who wished to be reunited with their relatives and who had a particular concern about immigration issues and went to migration agents for advice and assistance. Previously anybody could call himself or herself a migration agent. Unfortunately there was no power for this Parliament, and indeed for the law, to take action against those who made outlandish claims of influence and who charge outlandish fees. We now will have a schedule of fees. If the claims of influence that are made by the migration agents are shown to be false, action can be taken before the law. The point I would like to make very clearly here is, again, that there is duplicity in the Opposition's position. The Opposition states its position on immigration on page 39 of the Economic Action Plan:
Expenditure savings of $20 million will be achieved in this portfolio through improved administrative efficiencies and increasing cost recovery for migrant entry.

Perhaps that means it will increase the fee charged for visas but I suggest it means a thinning down of the bureaucracy. At the same time the office of the shadow spokesman for immigration is saying that the capacity of the Department to act on these matters is limited. I am suggesting that if the Opposition wants more scrutiny from the Department, if it wants to improve its performance--

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for North Sydney came in here bleeding for those who find themselves in difficult circumstances in China. I suggest that someone in China who can find $10,000 to come to Australia has perhaps an ulterior motive. Maybe that point needs to be considered. It is perfectly reasonable that Australia set guidelines and criteria for visa entry. It is perfectly reasonable that we have ministerial discretion as has been set out in this legislation because it is fair and objective and it does not provide privilege to those who do not deserve it. It is perfectly fair and reasonable that those guidelines that we have set down in this legislation, which improve the ability of the consumer to take action against a migration agent, should be followed through.

Because of the lateness of the hour I do not wish to say much more. However, those issues are important to those on this side of the House. TALK.START.PARA: —I take part in this debate because I want to use this opportunity to talk about the different position in which self-supporting retirees are placed as compared with sponsored aged relative migrants to this country. I also want to examine the changes that have been taking place in the relative positions of each of those migrant groups.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that our economy is in need of substantial change if we are to overcome some of the basic difficulties, including our huge balance of payments deficit. Under the migration legislation we admit people to this country who we hope will generate resources that will help us overcome those difficulties. Amongst those, of course, are the permanent migrants. But we also admit tourists. They enter on visitors visas which are temporary entry permits. We admit students to come here and study and they are admitted on a visa which, by its nature, is a temporary entry permit. We admit retirees. Retirees, however, now fall into two categories. The first is aged dependent relatives and the second used to be called self-supporting retirees, but now the visa under which they enter has been changed in character.

Until December 1988, those admitted under both of the categories to which I have referred were admitted on permanent entry visas. Now, aged dependent relatives are approved for admission and continue to be eligible to receive a permanent entry visa if they pass all of the other qualification tests. However, self-supporting retirees, if approved for admission, are now eligible only to receive extended stay visas. This is a new and interesting concept. Permanent residency gives to the person who enters this country with that type of visa the right to remain here permanently; eligibility for social security benefits and pensions subject to permanent residency for a qualifying period; eligibility for Medicare benefits; and further, eligibility to become an Australian citizen subject to permanent residency for the qualifying period and satisfying the various character tests.

On the other hand, the extended stay visa now available to self-supporting retirees denies them the right to apply for permanent resident status and denies them access to social security pensions and benefits because eligibility for those pensions and benefits depends on permanent residency for a qualifying period, and their living in Australia does not qualify them because they are not here on a permanent resident visa. It denies them access to Medicare benefits. It denies them the right to apply for Australian citizenship, as eligibility for Australian citizenship depends upon permanent residency and residency with such a visa for a qualifying period.

I am not suggesting that self-supporting retirees should be put into any changed position from that in which they are now placed, but I want to look at various aspects of the difference in the way in which we are treating aged people who are given the right to come and live here permanently or on an extended stay visa. It is a pre-condition of an entry permit being granted to an aged person that some form of assurance be given that the retiree will not become the responsibility of the general community, for five years in the case of an aged dependent relative and for the whole period of the temporary residence in the case of the extended stay retiree.

Let us for a moment examine the nature of the assurance that must be given. A self-supporting retiree now not admitted as a permanent resident but on an extended stay visa must have at least $500,000 capital for transfer to Australia-one might question why-or at least $150,000 capital for transfer and an annual income in excess of $35,000.

With regard to these people, concerns have been expressed, will continue to be expressed and must be expressed as to what checks are made in respect of the transfers to and the retention of the assets in Australia. As I mentioned a minute ago, why require the transfer? Is not their self-supporting living on an income making an economic contribution to Australia just as a tourist coming to Australia and living on an income brought in from overseas is making a contribution to Australia? The important thing is that in both cases neither the tourist nor the long-stay retiree should have a right to draw on our social security system, our Medicare system, our nursing home system or, indeed, other public sector responsibilities discharged by the Australian Government in respect of Australian citizens who have spent their whole working lives here.

Approval for an applicant to extend a long-stay visa, originally granted for four years, is not necessarily automatic, so one may ask who would transfer $500,000 to Australia without some longer term assurance that that person could stay. Such people should be able to stay if they are good citizens and provided that they are not a drain on the Australian social security and other public sector-funded schemes. Under the present arrangement they can stay for only four years. They cannot be assured of a renewal of their visa, although they may apply for a renewal and it will probably be granted. They then have to be able to establish that the assets they have in Australia are of a value equal to the requirements then required. Who knows whether the requirement will be $500,000 or $5m in four years time? That is the risk that these people run. There is no assurance that they will be able to stay provided that their assets have maintained, for example, an inflation factor. That may be the understanding, but it is not in the rules and regulations as they presently exist.

Why do we not grant permission to these people to enter on the basis that they are prepared to give an undertaking not to make any call on social security benefits, fringe benefits or other benefits scheme, Medicare, publicly funded nursing homes, et cetera and that they have enough income to support themselves? That has an economic value in itself. They would not necessarily have to transfer their assets to Australia if those assets are earning income overseas, as are the assets of many Australians. It is to be hoped that they would make a business judgment that this is a good place to invest some of their savings and if they chose to do so they should be allowed to, but they should not be forced to do so.

Someone will ask how we can be sure that they will not become destitute, need hospital treatment, be without an income and ask for a social security pension or special benefit of some form or other. We could require that these people not only give an undertaking, but also back up that undertaking with what I would describe as a performance bond from some approved financial institution. Performance bonds are not unheard of. In many transactions a party gives an undertaking but is then required to provide from a third party some form of performance bond. These people could go to a recognised, perhaps listed, financial institution and get the performance bond required. In the event of such persons having inadequate resources, the third party bond grantor would meet any liabilities incurred by the Commonwealth Government in respect of those retirees' failure to meet their undertaking not to make a call on social security, Medicare, nursing home or other publicly funded sectors. If this undertaking is given, why then limit to four years the period for which a self-supporting retiree may enter Australia? Why require such people to transfer assets to Australia? Why not grant them the right to stay here indefinitely, still on a long-stay visa which could then be withdrawn in the event of a default under the guarantee, so that they do not acquire Australian citizenship or permanent residency rights?

Let us look at the case of aged dependent relatives. Under existing arrangements, after five years of residence of retirees sponsored by a relative, we take public sector responsibility for their social expenditure in the same way as we have taken that responsi- bility for someone who has been here for 55 years. However, in many cases the com- munity is required to take responsibility for these aged dependent relatives for a substantial proportion of their first five years in Australia. This is because the guarantees of sponsors, obtained as a precondition to the grant of an entry permit, have in many instances proved not worth the paper they were written on.

However, from April this year the procedure has been changed but in my view will nevertheless prove inadequate to ensure that sponsors or the Australian citizens who provide the assurance of support meet the obligation that these assurances of support involve. The procedures now laid down require migration officers to conduct pre- migration checks of an assuror's ability to honour a five-year assurance. Frankly, I believe it should not be limited to five years. We should consider making the assuror responsible for the whole of a person's period in Australia if that person is aged 60 or 65 or more and can make no contribution to the Australian economy other than perhaps to bring some investments.

But are our migration officers really trained and experienced in testing the creditworthiness of those who offer assurances? What do they have to do? They are told by the departmental regulations that they have to check whether the person offering to provide the assurance has received any welfare payment in the previous 12 months. So be it. But what about that person's likelihood of receiving a welfare payment in the next five years or during the period over which the assurance is supposed to be of some value to the public sector? The migration officers are supposed to check whether an assuror has previously defaulted in meeting obligations under an assurance of support. They are supposed then to test whether the assuror has the current ability to honour his proposed obligations. But we are talking about an ability in four or five years time. Departmental officers are instructed that they must ask assurors to provide their latest income tax assessment, current pay slip, evidence of major assets, including housing, bank slips and so on, confirmation of liabilities for housing repayments, hire purchase liabilities and credit card obligations. They all relate to current liabilities. But what about the future? They must also ask for such other evidence-this is the all-sweet clause-as may establish their financial ability to meet obligations undertaken by giving the assurance of support.

I wonder whether migration officers really understand what testing the creditworthiness of an assuror involves. I have my doubts. I would be interested to learn whether they are put through training courses in the same way as bankers and officers working for credit-providing organisations are. I doubt it. But then an assuror's income is prima facie sufficient if the assuror is not eligible for a health care card. Assurors are regarded as having the capacity to pay the equivalent of the pension, to provide hospital and medical insurance for the relative being brought to Australia, if as a single person their income is $167 per week or, if they are married, their income is $278 or more, with an increase of $34 for each additional child they may have.

Where possible the officers are required, except when checking with the Department of Social Security to determine whether an assuror is receiving a pension or has defaulted on a previous assurance, to deal on the spot with the assessment of the ability to pay. I ask honourable members to contrast those requirements with the requirements that are imposed on the self-supporting retiree-$500,000 to be transferred to Australia or, if not $500,000, then $150,000 and an income of $673 per week. The way out of this different treatment of aged people who seek to retire in Australia because they have friends here, because they like the place or because they have relatives here should be to treat them all the same. They should be viewed in the same way as students who come here and pay university fees on a user pays basis. We should treat them as tourists who come to Australia and pay on a user pays basis. We should welcome them, because it will expand our foreign currency transfers to this country.

We should require people in Australia who sponsor retirees to provide an assurance of support for the lifetime of the aged relatives. Those assurances of support should be backed up by the sort of performance bond that I have advocated in respect of the self-supporting retiree. Those bonds should be required from recognised Australian financial institutions. Sponsored aged relatives should be granted indefinite stay visas rather than permanent resident visas-not short term visas or long stay visas but indefinite stay visas. Those visas should continue to be valid except if those migrants default. Then they can be deported either in the way in which people are deported under existing arrangements or if they default by making a significant or substantial claim on the public sector social expenditure liabilities that are provided for Australians who have spent their working lives in this country.

This whole matter needs to be very carefully considered. The marketplace would establish a fee for organisations such as third party guarantors and the parties that provide performance bonds. Fees have been established for existing types of performance bonds. For some, a fee would be set and some sort of charge would be taken over the assets, or perhaps a pension from some other source of the person who is asking for it. The fee would vary according to the commercial assessment of the likelihood of the retiree either not supporting himself or herself or not being supported by the relative or friend in Australia. That would free up the migration process for the relatives and friends in Australia who want to bring aged relatives from overseas, whether they are parents, brothers or sisters. Those people would not have to be tested on the basis of whether or not they were going to be a drain on the Australian economy because, in effect, they would be coming here on a user pays basis. They would have to pay for their own social expenditures, or those who were giving the guarantee would have to do so. In that way many Australian residents would be able to bring to Australia their brothers, sisters, friends and other relatives simply on the basis that they could then clearly establish that they would not come back onto the social security system.
